notes.title: Scope and Domains
points: Physics is the study of the fundamental laws of nature and their manifestation in various phenomena.
Macroscopic Domain: Studies large-scale phenomena (Classical Physics - Mechanics, Thermodynamics, etc.).
Microscopic Domain: Studies atomic and subatomic phenomena (Quantum Physics).
Mesoscopic Domain: Intermediate level between macro and micro.

formulas.title: Magnitude Range
formulas.explanation: Range of length scales studied in physics, from the radius of a nucleus to the size of the observable universe.

realworld.title: GPS Systems
realworld.description: GPS technology relies on both General and Special Relativity to synchronize satellite clocks with Earth clocks for precise positioning.

realworld.title: Semiconductor Devices
realworld.description: Modern electronics like smartphones and computers use semiconductors designed using macroscopic effects of quantum mechanics.

notes.title: Conservation Laws
points: Fundamental laws are often related to certain symmetries in nature (space, time).
Law of Conservation of Energy: Total energy remains constant.
Law of Conservation of Momentum (Linear and Angular).
Law of Conservation of Charge.

formulas.title: Energy-Mass Relation
formulas.explanation: Einstein's mass-energy equivalence formula, showing mass is another form of energy.

realworld.title: Nuclear Power Plants
realworld.description: Fission of nuclei converts a small amount of mass into a huge amount of thermal energy used to generate electricity.

notes.title: Interdependence
points: Physics often leads to new technology (e.g., thermodynamics led to steam engines).
Technology provides tools for physics research (e.g., particle accelerators).
Physics has social impact through medical advancements, communication, and sustainability.

realworld.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
realworld.description: MRI uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves, a direct application of spin physics, to image soft tissues in humans.

notes.title: The Four Forces
points: Gravitational Force: Always attractive, long range, infinite reach, obeys inverse square law.
Electromagnetic Force: Between charges, attractive or repulsive, long range, very strong compared to gravity.
Strong Nuclear Force: Holds nucleus together, short range (~10⁻¹⁵ m), strongest force.
Weak Nuclear Force: Responsible for radioactive decay (beta decay), short range (~10⁻¹⁶ m).

formulas.title: Relative Strengths
formulas.explanation: Approximate relative strengths of Strong, Electromagnetic, Weak, and Gravitational forces respectively.

realworld.title: Sun's Energy
realworld.description: The strong nuclear force overcomes proton-proton repulsion to facilitate fusion, providing the energy that powers stars.

notes.title: Measurement Basics
points: A physical quantity is measured by comparing it to a standard called a unit.
Measure (Q) = Numerical value (n) × Unit (u). If unit changes, n changes such that nu = constant.
Characteristics of a good unit: Well-defined, invariable, accessible, and reproducible.

formulas.title: Measurement Equation
formulas.explanation: The product of the numerical value and the size of the unit remains constant for different unit systems.

realworld.title: International Trade
realworld.description: Standard units ensure that a 'kilogram' of wheat in India is the same as a 'kilogram' in the USA, enabling fair trade.

notes.title: International System
points: Le Système International d'Unités (SI) is a decimal system.
Adopted in 1960 for global scientific and industrial consistency.
Includes 7 Base Units and 2 Supplementary Units (Radian and Steradian).

formulas.title: Angle Formulas
formulas.explanation: Formulas for plane angle and solid angle using supplementary SI units.

realworld.title: Engineering Plans
realworld.description: Engineers use SI units like meters and Newtons to ensure bridge components manufactured in different factories fit perfectly.

notes.title: Types of Units
points: Base (Fundamental) Units: Independent units (Mass, Length, Time, Temperature, Current, Amount of Substance, Luminous Intensity).
Derived Units: Expressed as combinations of base units (e.g., Velocity = m/s, Force = kg m/s²).

formulas.title: Derived Unit Example (Force)
formulas.explanation: Force is a derived quantity combining mass, length, and time.

realworld.title: Cooking Recipes
realworld.description: Liters and cups are derived units of volume used daily to measure ingredients for baking.

topics.name: Measurement of Length, Mass and Time

notes.title: Measurement Methods
points: Direct Method: Using rulers, micrometers, or clocks.
Indirect Method: Parallax method for far objects (stars), Sonar for ocean depths.
Atomic Clocks: Use vibrations of cesium atoms for time measurement with extreme stability.

formulas.title: Parallax Method
formulas.explanation: Distance D to a star, where b is the basis (distance between observation points) and θ is the parallax angle.

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: Distances to other galaxies are measured in light-years (distance light travels in a year) using indirect radar and optical parallax methods.

notes.title: Measurement Quality
points: Accuracy: Closeness of the measured value to the true value. Depends on external factors and calibration.
Precision: Closeness of a set of measurements to each other. Depends on the least count of the instrument.
A measurement can be precise but inaccurate (e.g., a misaligned digital scale).

realworld.title: Archery
realworld.description: Hitting the center is accuracy; hitting the same spot repeatedly (even if not the center) is precision.

notes.title: Error Analysis
points: Absolute Error: Magnitude of difference between true value and individual measurement.
Mean Absolute Error: Arithmetic mean of all absolute errors.
Relative Error: Ratio of mean absolute error to the mean value.
Percentage Error: Relative error expressed in percent.

formulas.title: Percentage Error
formulas.explanation: The maximum percentage uncertainty expected in a measured quantity.

formulas.title: Combination of Errors (Addition)
formulas.explanation: Absolute error of a sum is the sum of individual absolute errors.

realworld.title: Drug Dosing
realworld.description: Pharmacists must account for measurement errors to ensure a patient receives a safe and effective dose of medication.

notes.title: Rules for Significance
points: All non-zero digits are significant.
Zeros between non-zero digits are significant.
Leading zeros are never significant.
Trailing zeros with a decimal point are significant; without a decimal, they are ambiguous (better to use scientific notation).

formulas.title: Arithmetic with Sig Figs
formulas.explanation: In addition/subtraction, result has same decimal places as value with least decimal places. In multiplication/division, result has same sig figs as value with least sig figs.

realworld.title: Civil Engineering
realworld.description: When measuring the length of a bridge, reporting it as '100.00 meters' implies a precision that must be justified by the instrument used.

notes.title: Dimensional Analysis
points: Dimensions are the powers to which the base units are raised to represent a physical quantity.
Seven base dimensions: [M], [L], [T], [I], [K], [mol], [cd].
Dimensional Formula: Expression showing which base dimensions are involved.

formulas.title: Dimension of Force
formulas.explanation: Force is mass × acceleration, so [M] × [L/T²].

formulas.title: Dimension of Energy
formulas.explanation: Energy has the same dimensions as work (Force × Displacement).

realworld.title: Scaling Models
realworld.description: Aeroengineers use dimensional constants to scale down real airplane results into wind-tunnel models using dimensionless numbers like Reynolds number.

notes.title: Practical Uses
points: Checking the correctness of an equation (Principle of Homogeneity).
Deriving relations between physical quantities.
Converting units from one system to another.

formulas.title: Unit Conversion
formulas.explanation: Formula used to find the value of a physical quantity in a new system of units.

realworld.title: Fluid Mechanics
realworld.description: Defining the behavior of water flow in pipes depends on dimensionless ratios that remain valid regardless of the unit system used.

notes.title: Definition and Types
points: A frame of reference is a coordinate system with time frame used to measure and observe physical quantities.
Inertial frames are those in which Newton's first law holds true (non-accelerating frames).
Non-inertial frames are accelerating frames where fictitious forces appear to act.
Earth is approximately an inertial frame for most everyday observations.

formulas.title: Galilean Transformation
formulas.explanation: Relates coordinates in two inertial frames moving at relative velocity v.

realworld.title: Moving Train Example
realworld.description: When a train moves at constant velocity, objects inside behave as if the train were at rest, demonstrating an inertial frame of reference.

realworld.title: Merry-go-round
realworld.description: A person on a rotating ride feels a centrifugal force, which is a fictitious force resulting from Being in a non-inertial (accelerating) frame.

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Rest: An object is said to be at rest if it does not change its position with respect to its surroundings.
Motion: An object is in motion if it changes its position with respect to its surroundings.
Motion is always relative to a frame of reference.
Absolute rest doesn't exist as there is no absolute frame of reference in the universe.

formulas.title: Relative Velocity
formulas.explanation: Velocity of A relative to B is the vector difference of their velocities relative to a common frame (ground).

realworld.title: Earth's Rotation
realworld.description: A building appears at rest relative to Earth's surface but is actually in motion due to Earth's rotation and revolution.

notes.title: Scalar Quantities
points: Have only magnitude (size) but no direction.
Examples: Mass, distance, speed, time, temperature, energy.
Follow ordinary rules of algebra for addition, subtraction, multiplication, etc.

notes.title: Vector Quantities
points: Have both magnitude and direction.
Examples: Displacement, velocity, acceleration, force, momentum.
Follow vector algebra for mathematical operations.
Represented graphically by arrows where length represents magnitude and arrowhead indicates direction.

formulas.title: Vector Addition (Triangle Law)
formulas.explanation: The resultant vector R is obtained by placing the tail of B at the head of A and drawing a vector from the tail of A to the head of B.

formulas.title: Vector Subtraction
formulas.explanation: Subtracting vector B from A is equivalent to adding A and the negative of B.

realworld.title: Boat Crossing a River
realworld.description: A boat's actual velocity is the vector sum of its velocity relative to water and the water's current velocity.

notes.title: Key Definitions
points: Position: The location of an object relative to a reference point.
Path Length (Distance): Total length of the actual path traversed by an object. It's a scalar quantity.
Displacement: The shortest distance between the initial and final positions of an object. It's a vector quantity.
Displacement can be zero even when distance is not zero (e.g., circular motion returning to start).

formulas.title: Displacement in 1D
formulas.explanation: Change in position (displacement) equals final position minus initial position.

realworld.title: Morning Walk
realworld.description: If you walk 5 km east and then 3 km west, your distance is 8 km but displacement is only 2 km east.

notes.title: Speed
points: Scalar quantity representing how fast an object is moving.
Average speed = Total distance / Total time
Instantaneous speed is the speed at a particular instant of time.

notes.title: Velocity
points: Vector quantity representing both speed and direction of motion.
Average velocity = Displacement / Time interval
Instantaneous velocity is the velocity at a particular instant of time.
Uniform velocity means constant speed and direction.

formulas.title: Average Speed
formulas.explanation: The total path length traveled divided by the total time interval.

formulas.title: Average Velocity
formulas.explanation: Displacement divided by the time interval.

realworld.title: Car Speedometer vs GPS
realworld.description: A car's speedometer shows instantaneous speed, while a GPS can calculate velocity by tracking position changes over time, including direction.

notes.title: Understanding Acceleration
points: Rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
Vector quantity with both magnitude and direction.
Can be positive (speeding up), negative (slowing down), or zero (constant velocity).
Occurs when either speed changes or direction of motion changes, or both.

formulas.title: Average Acceleration
formulas.explanation: Change in velocity divided by the time interval over which the change occurs.

formulas.title: Instantaneous Acceleration
formulas.explanation: The derivative of velocity with respect to time, representing acceleration at an exact moment.

realworld.title: Car Braking
realworld.description: When a car applies brakes, it experiences negative acceleration (deceleration), causing the speed to decrease over time.

notes.title: Uniform Motion
points: Object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time.
Velocity remains constant (no acceleration).
Position-time graph is a straight line with constant slope.
Velocity-time graph is a horizontal line.

notes.title: Non-uniform Motion
points: Object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time.
Velocity changes with time (acceleration is present).
Position-time graph is a curve.
Velocity-time graph has a non-zero slope.

formulas.title: Uniform Motion Condition
formulas.explanation: In uniform motion, velocity does not change with time, and acceleration is zero.

formulas.title: Non-uniform Motion Condition
formulas.explanation: In non-uniform motion, velocity changes with time, indicating the presence of acceleration.

realworld.title: Train Journey
realworld.description: A train's motion includes periods of uniform motion (constant speed), positive acceleration (leaving station), and negative acceleration (approaching station).

notes.title: Key Equations
points: Applicable only for uniformly accelerated motion.
Derived from definitions of velocity and acceleration.
Can be used to solve problems involving motion in one dimension.
Require knowledge of at least three variables to solve for others.

formulas.title: First Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Final velocity (v) equals initial velocity (u) plus acceleration (a) multiplied by time (t).

formulas.title: Second Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Displacement (s) equals initial velocity (u) times time (t) plus half acceleration (a) times time squared.

formulas.title: Third Equation of Motion
formulas.explanation: Final velocity squared equals initial velocity squared plus two times acceleration times displacement.

formulas.title: Displacement in nth Second
formulas.explanation: Displacement in the nth second of motion.

realworld.title: Free Fall
realworld.description: Objects in free fall near Earth's surface accelerate at approximately 9.8 m/s² downward, allowing us to calculate their position and velocity at any time.

notes.title: Position-Time Graphs
points: Slope represents velocity.
Straight line: constant velocity.
Curved line: changing velocity (acceleration).
Horizontal line: object at rest.

notes.title: Velocity-Time Graphs
points: Slope represents acceleration.
Area under the curve represents displacement.
Horizontal line: constant velocity (zero acceleration).
Straight line with non-zero slope: constant acceleration.

notes.title: Acceleration-Time Graphs
points: Area under the curve represents change in velocity.
Horizontal line: constant acceleration.
Zero line: constant velocity.

formulas.title: Slope of Graph
formulas.explanation: Slope of a curve at any point represents the rate of change of y with respect to x.

formulas.title: Area Under Graph
formulas.explanation: The integral representing the space between the curve and the x-axis, used to find displacement from a v-t graph.

realworld.title: Car's Speedometer and Odometer
realworld.description: A car's speedometer provides velocity-time data that could be graphed, while the odometer tracks distance traveled, similar to the area under a velocity-time curve.

notes.title: Two-Dimensional Motion
points: Motion that occurs in two perpendicular directions simultaneously.
Can be analyzed by resolving into x and y components.
Projectile motion is a special case of motion in a plane.
Relative motion in two dimensions follows vector addition rules.

notes.title: Relative Velocity in Two Dimensions
points: v_AB = v_A - v_B
Where v_AB is velocity of A relative to B.
Important for problems involving boats in rivers, airplanes in wind, etc.
Can be solved using vector components or trigonometric methods.

formulas.title: Relative Velocity in 2D
formulas.explanation: The velocity of object A relative to object B is the vector difference of their velocities.

formulas.title: Position Vector in 2D
formulas.explanation: Position vector in two dimensions using unit vectors along x and y axes.

realworld.title: Boat Crossing a River
realworld.description: A boat's actual path across a river is the vector sum of its velocity relative to water and the water's current velocity.

notes.title: Key Characteristics
points: Two-dimensional motion under constant acceleration due to gravity.
Horizontal motion has constant velocity (a_x = 0).
Vertical motion has constant acceleration (a_y = -g).
Path is a parabola (neglecting air resistance).

notes.title: Important Points
points: Time of flight depends only on initial vertical velocity.
Maximum height depends on initial vertical velocity.
Range is maximum when projection angle is 45° (in vacuum).
At maximum height, vertical velocity is zero.

formulas.title: Time of Flight
formulas.explanation: Total time the projectile remains in the air, where u is initial velocity and θ is projection angle.

formulas.title: Maximum Height
formulas.explanation: Maximum vertical displacement reached by the projectile.

formulas.title: Horizontal Range
formulas.explanation: Horizontal distance covered during the time of flight.

formulas.title: Equation of Trajectory
formulas.explanation: Path followed by the projectile in the x-y plane.

realworld.title: Basketball Shot
realworld.description: A basketball follows a parabolic trajectory when shot, with its path determined by initial speed and angle of projection.

realworld.title: Long Jump
realworld.description: Long jumpers aim for a takeoff angle around 20-25° rather than 45° because their center of mass is not at the same level at takeoff and landing.

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Motion of an object at constant speed along a circular path.
Velocity is always tangent to the circular path.
Centripetal acceleration is always directed toward the center.
Period (T) is the time for one complete revolution.
Frequency (f) is the number of revolutions per unit time.

notes.title: Key Relationships
points: Angular velocity (ω) = 2π/T = 2πf
Linear velocity (v) = rω
Centripetal acceleration (a_c) = v²/r = rω²
Centripetal force (F_c) = mv²/r = mrω²

formulas.title: Centripetal Acceleration
formulas.explanation: Acceleration directed toward the center of the circular path, responsible for changing the direction of velocity.

formulas.title: Centripetal Force
formulas.explanation: Net force required to keep an object moving in a circular path, always directed toward the center.

formulas.title: Time Period
formulas.explanation: Time taken to complete one full revolution.

formulas.title: Frequency
formulas.explanation: Number of complete revolutions per unit time.

realworld.title: Car Taking a Turn
realworld.description: When a car takes a turn, the frictional force between tires and road provides the necessary centripetal force to keep the car moving in a circular path.

realworld.title: Satellite Orbit
realworld.description: Satellites in circular orbit around Earth experience centripetal acceleration provided by Earth's gravitational force, keeping them in stable orbits.

realworld.title: Washing Machine Spin Cycle
realworld.description: The spin cycle uses circular motion to create a centripetal force that pulls water out of clothes, with the drum's holes allowing water to escape while keeping clothes inside.

notes.title: Understanding Force
points: Force is a push or pull that can change the state of motion or shape of an object.
SI unit of force is Newton (N), where 1 N = 1 kg·m/s².
Forces can be contact forces (friction, normal force) or non-contact forces (gravity, magnetic force).
Forces are vector quantities with both magnitude and direction.

notes.title: Understanding Inertia
points: Inertia is the property of an object to resist changes in its state of motion.
Directly related to the mass of an object - greater mass means greater inertia.
Explains why it's harder to push a heavy object than a light one.
The natural tendency of objects to continue in their current state (at rest or in motion).

formulas.title: Force (Newton's Second Law)
formulas.explanation: Force equals mass times acceleration. This is the fundamental relationship between force and motion.

realworld.title: Seatbelts in Cars
realworld.description: Seatbelts prevent passengers from continuing their forward motion (due to inertia) when a car suddenly stops, demonstrating how inertia affects objects in motion.

realworld.title: Shaking a Ketchup Bottle
realworld.description: The ketchup inside a bottle resists motion due to inertia. A quick downward jerk overcomes this inertia, causing the ketchup to move relative to the bottle.

notes.title: Law of Inertia
points: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
Also known as the Law of Inertia.
Defines the concept of inertia and introduces the idea of equilibrium.
Explains why objects don't move on their own or stop moving without a force.

notes.title: Key Implications
points: No net force means no acceleration (but the object could be moving at constant velocity).
In the absence of external forces, an object's velocity remains constant.
Friction and air resistance are forces that often prevent observation of this law in everyday life.
In space, where friction is minimal, objects continue moving indefinitely unless acted upon.

formulas.title: Equilibrium Condition
formulas.explanation: The vector sum of all forces acting on an object is zero when it's in equilibrium (either at rest or moving with constant velocity).

realworld.title: Passengers in a Braking Bus
realworld.description: When a moving bus suddenly brakes, passengers continue moving forward due to inertia, which is why they lurch forward in their seats.

realworld.title: Tablecloth Trick
realworld.description: Pulling a tablecloth quickly from under dishes demonstrates how objects at rest tend to stay at rest due to inertia.

realworld.title: Astronauts in Space
realworld.concept: Motion in the Absence of Forces
realworld.description: In the microgravity of space, objects continue moving at constant velocity unless acted upon by a force, perfectly illustrating Newton's First Law.

notes.title: Fundamental Principle
points: The rate of change of linear momentum of a body is directly proportional to the applied force.
The change in momentum takes place in the direction of the applied force.
This law quantifies force: F = ma (for constant mass).

notes.title: Component Form
points: Force vectors can be resolved into components: Fx = max, Fy = may, Fz = maz.
This allows solving complex problems by treating motion in each dimension independently.

formulas.title: Mathematical Form
formulas.explanation: Force is the derivative of momentum (p) with respect to time (t).

formulas.title: Constant Mass
formulas.explanation: If mass is constant, Force = mass × acceleration.

realworld.title: Catching a Cricket Ball
realworld.description: A player pulls their hands back while catching a fast ball to increase the time of impact, thereby reducing the rate of change of momentum and the force felt on the hands.

notes.title: Action and Reaction
points: To every action, there is always an equal and opposite reaction.
Action and reaction forces act on two different bodies.
They act simultaneously; there is no time lag between action and reaction.
Since they act on different bodies, they do not cancel each other out.

formulas.title: Vector Form
formulas.explanation: Force exerted by A on B is equal and opposite to force exerted by B on A.

realworld.title: Walking
realworld.description: We push the ground backward (Action), and the ground pushes us forward with an equal force (Reaction), enabling us to walk.

realworld.title: Rocket Launch
realworld.description: The rocket pushes exhaust gases downward, and the gases push the rocket upward.

notes.title: Definition
points: Linear momentum is the quantity of motion contained in a body.
It is the product of mass and velocity.
It is a vector quantity having the same direction as velocity.
SI Unit: kg m/s.

formulas.title: Linear Momentum
formulas.explanation: p = momentum, m = mass, v = velocity.

realworld.title: Heavy vs Light Vehicle
realworld.description: A heavy truck moving at the same speed as a small car has much more momentum, making it harder to stop.

notes.title: Concept
points: Impulse is the effect of a large force acting for a short duration.
It is defined as the product of force and time duration (J = F × Δt).
Impulse is also equal to the total change in momentum (Impulse-Momentum Theorem).

formulas.title: Impulse
formulas.explanation: Impulse equals Average Force times time interval, which equals change in momentum (pf - pi).

realworld.title: Hitting a Nail
realworld.description: A hammer delivers a large impulse to a nail in a very short time, driving it into wood.

realworld.title: Airbags
realworld.description: Airbags increase the time of collision for the passenger, reducing the average force exerted on them (since Δp is constant).

topics.name: Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum

notes.title: Statement
points: If no external force acts on a system of particles, the total linear momentum of the system remains constant.
Formula: m1u1 + m2u2 = m1v1 + m2v2 (for collision of two bodies).

formulas.title: Conservation Formula
formulas.explanation: Total initial momentum equals total final momentum in an isolated system.

realworld.title: Recoil of a Gun
realworld.description: When a bullet is fired forward, the gun recoils backward to conserve total momentum (which was zero initially).

notes.title: Conditions
points: Concurrent forces are forces whose lines of action intersect at a common point.
A body is in equilibrium if the vector sum of all concurrent forces acting on it is zero.
Lami's Theorem: Relates magnitude of three coplanar concurrent forces in equilibrium to the sine of angles between them.

formulas.title: Equilibrium Condition
formulas.explanation: Net force is zero in all directions.

formulas.title: Lami's Theorem
formulas.explanation: For three forces in equilibrium, proportional to sine of opposite angles.

realworld.title: Suspended Lamp
realworld.description: A lamp hanging from a ceiling is in equilibrium under the action of tension in the cord (upward) and gravity (downward).

notes.title: Friction Basics
points: Friction opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact.
Static Friction (fs): Self-adjusting force that prevents motion up to a limit (limiting friction).
Kinetic Friction (fk): Opposes motion when the body is actually moving.
Generally, limiting friction > kinetic friction.

notes.title: Laws of Friction
points: Friction is directly proportional to Normal Reaction (N).
It depends on the nature of surfaces, not on the apparent area of contact.

formulas.title: Static Friction
formulas.explanation: μs is coefficient of static friction, N is normal force. Max value is fs_max = μsN.

formulas.title: Kinetic Friction
formulas.explanation: μk is coefficient of kinetic friction.

realworld.title: Walking on Ice
realworld.description: It is difficult to walk on ice because the coefficient of friction is very low, providing insufficient grip.

realworld.title: Brakes
realworld.description: Brake pads use friction to convert kinetic energy of the wheel into heat, slowing down the vehicle.

notes.title: Dynamics
points: To move in a circle, a body requires a net force directed towards the center, called Centripetal Force.
It is not a new force but provided by existing forces (Tension, Friction, Gravity).
Centrifugal Force: A pseudo force experienced in a rotating (non-inertial) frame, directed outwards.

notes.title: Banked Roads
points: Roads are banked (tilted) at curves to reduce reliance on friction for providing centripetal force.
Allows vehicles to turn safely at higher speeds.

formulas.title: Centripetal Force
formulas.explanation: Force required to keep mass m moving at speed v in circle of radius r.

formulas.title: Safe Speed on Banked Road
formulas.explanation: Maximum safe velocity on a banked curve with friction.

formulas.title: Bending of Cyclist
formulas.explanation: Angle made with vertical to negotiate a turn.

realworld.title: Cream Separator
realworld.description: Heavier milk particles are pushed outwards (centrifugal effect in rotating frame), leaving lighter cream at the center.

realworld.title: Death Well (Maut ka Kuan)
realworld.description: Motorcyclists drive on vertical walls because the normal reaction provides centripetal force, and friction balances weight.

topics.name: Work Done by a Constant Force

notes.title: Understanding Work in Physics
points: Work is done when a force causes a displacement in the direction of the force.
Work is a scalar quantity measured in Joules (J) in the SI system.
No work is done if there is no displacement, even if a force is applied.
Work can be positive (force and displacement in same direction) or negative (force and displacement in opposite directions).

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: Work depends on the magnitude of force, displacement, and the angle between them.
Maximum work is done when force and displacement are parallel (θ = 0°).
No work is done when force is perpendicular to displacement (θ = 90°).
Negative work indicates energy is being taken away from the object.

formulas.title: Work Done by Constant Force
formulas.explanation: Work (W) equals the dot product of force (F) and displacement (s) vectors, where θ is the angle between them.

formulas.title: Work in One Dimension
formulas.formula: W = F·s (when force and displacement are parallel)
formulas.explanation: Simplified form when force and displacement are in the same direction (θ = 0°).

formulas.title: Work Done Against Gravity
formulas.explanation: Work done in lifting an object of mass m to height h against gravity (g = 9.8 m/s²).

realworld.title: Pushing a Shopping Cart
realworld.description: When you push a shopping cart forward, you're doing positive work. The amount of work depends on the force applied and the distance pushed.

realworld.title: Holding a Heavy Object
realworld.description: When you hold a heavy object stationary, no work is done on the object because there is no displacement, even though you're applying an upward force equal to its weight.

realworld.title: Braking a Moving Car
realworld.description: When brakes are applied to a moving car, the frictional force does negative work on the car, causing it to lose kinetic energy and slow down.

realworld.title: Satellite in Circular Orbit
realworld.description: The gravitational force on a satellite in a circular orbit does no work because the force is always perpendicular to the displacement (instantaneous velocity), maintaining the satellite's speed but not changing its kinetic energy.

notes.title: Understanding Variable Forces
points: Variable forces change in magnitude, direction, or both during the displacement.
Common examples include spring forces, gravitational forces over large distances, and air resistance.
Work done by variable forces cannot be calculated using the simple formula W = F·s·cosθ.
Requires integration techniques for precise calculation of work done.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: The work done by a variable force is equal to the area under the force-displacement graph.
For one-dimensional motion, work is calculated by integrating the force function with respect to displacement.
The direction of the force relative to displacement must be considered at each point.
Variable forces often appear in systems with changing configurations or non-constant accelerations.

formulas.title: Work Done by Variable Force (1D)
formulas.explanation: Work done by a one-dimensional variable force F(x) as the object moves from position x₁ to x₂.

formulas.title: Spring Force (Hooke's Law)
formulas.explanation: The restoring force (F) exerted by a spring is proportional to its displacement (x) from equilibrium, with k being the spring constant.

formulas.title: Work Done on a Spring
formulas.explanation: Work done in stretching or compressing a spring by displacement x from its natural length.

realworld.title: Stretching a Rubber Band
realworld.description: As you stretch a rubber band, the force required increases with displacement, following Hooke's Law until the elastic limit is reached.

realworld.title: Rocket Launch
realworld.description: As a rocket burns fuel, its mass decreases while the thrust remains constant, resulting in increasing acceleration - a classic example of work done by variable forces.

realworld.title: Bungee Jumping
realworld.description: The bungee cord exerts a variable force that increases with stretch, converting the jumper's kinetic energy into elastic potential energy.

realworld.title: Pumping Air into a Bicycle Tire
realworld.description: As more air is pumped into a tire, the pressure increases, requiring more work to add each subsequent volume of air against the increasing back pressure.

notes.title: Definition
points: Energy possessed by a body by virtue of its motion.
It is a scalar quantity and is always positive.
Depends on mass and magnitude of velocity (speed).

formulas.title: Kinetic Energy
formulas.explanation: m = mass, v = velocity.

formulas.title: Relation with Momentum
formulas.explanation: p = linear momentum.

realworld.title: Speeding Car
realworld.description: A car traveling at high speed has large kinetic energy, which causes significant damage during a collision.

notes.title: Statement
points: Work done by the net force on a body is equal to the change in its kinetic energy.
Valid for both constant and variable forces.
Work done can be positive (KE increases) or negative (KE decreases).

formulas.title: Work-Energy Theorem
formulas.formula: W_net = ΔKE = KE_f - KE_i = ½m(v² - u²)
formulas.explanation: W_net is work done by all forces.

realworld.title: Stopping Distance
realworld.description: When you brake, friction does negative work on the car, reducing its kinetic energy to zero.

notes.title: Definition
points: Energy possessed by a body by virtue of its position or configuration.
Gravitational Potential Energy: Due to height above ground.
Elastic Potential Energy: Due to deformation (stretching/compressing).

formulas.title: Gravitational Potential Energy
formulas.explanation: Near Earth's surface, h = height.

formulas.title: Spring Potential Energy
formulas.explanation: k = spring constant, x = displacement.

realworld.title: Dam Water
realworld.description: Water stored at a height in a dam has potential energy which is converted to kinetic energy to turn turbines.

realworld.title: Bow and Arrow
realworld.description: A stretched bow stores elastic potential energy, which transfers to the arrow as kinetic energy upon release.

notes.title: Conservative Forces
points: Work done depends only on initial and final positions, not on path taken.
Work done in a closed path is zero.
Examples: Gravitational force, Electrostatic force, Spring force.

notes.title: Non-conservative Forces
points: Work done depends on the path taken.
Work done in a closed path is not zero (energy is dissipated).
Examples: Friction, Air resistance, Viscous force.

formulas.title: Conservative Force Work
formulas.explanation: Work done by a conservative force equals the negative change in potential energy.

formulas.title: Closed Path Work (Conservative)
formulas.explanation: Total work done by a conservative force over any closed loop is zero.

realworld.title: Energy Recovery in Springs
realworld.description: Mechanical watches use the conservative nature of spring forces to store and release energy with minimal loss.

realworld.title: Brake Overheating
realworld.description: Brakes convert kinetic energy into heat through friction (a non-conservative force), which is why they get hot and cannot recover the lost energy.

topics.name: Law of Conservation of Mechanical Energy

notes.title: Principle
points: If only conservative forces act on a system, the total mechanical energy (KE + PE) remains constant.
Energy can transform between potential and kinetic forms.

formulas.title: Conservation Formula
formulas.explanation: Initial mechanical energy = Final mechanical energy.

realworld.title: Roller Coaster
realworld.description: At the top of a loop, the coaster has max PE and min KE. At the bottom, it has min PE and max KE.

realworld.title: Simple Pendulum
realworld.description: Energy oscillates between kinetic (at mean position) and potential (at extreme positions); sum is constant.

notes.title: Power
points: Rate of doing work.
Scalar quantity.
SI Unit: Watt (W) = J/s. Practical Unit: Horsepower (hp) = 746 W.

notes.title: Efficiency
points: Ratio of output power to input power.
Always less than 1 (or 100%) for real machines due to energy losses.

formulas.title: Average Power
formulas.explanation: Work done per unit time.

formulas.title: Instantaneous Power
formulas.explanation: Dot product of force and velocity.

realworld.title: Car Engine
realworld.description: Car engines are rated in horsepower, indicating how fast they can do work (accelerate the car).

realworld.title: Light Bulbs
realworld.description: A 100W bulb converts electrical energy into light and heat at a rate of 100 Joules per second.

realworld.title: Stairs vs Elevator
realworld.description: Running up stairs requires more power than walking, as the same amount of work (mgh) is done in less time.

notes.title: Types of Collisions
points: Elastic Collision: KE and Momentum both conserved. (e.g., atomic collisions, billiard balls approx).
Inelastic Collision: Momentum conserved, but KE is not conserved (loss as heat/sound).
Perfectly Inelastic: Bodies stick together after collision and move with common velocity (max KE loss).

notes.title: Coefficient of Restitution (e)
points: Measure of elasticity of collision.
e = Velocity of separation / Velocity of approach.
e = 1 (Elastic), 0 < e < 1 (Inelastic), e = 0 (Perfectly inelastic).

formulas.title: Elastic Collision (1D)
formulas.explanation: Final velocity of mass m1.

formulas.title: Coefficient of Restitution
formulas.explanation: Ratio of relative velocities.

realworld.title: Bouncing Ball
realworld.description: A ball dropped on the floor doesn't reach the original height because some energy is lost (inelastic collision with the floor).

realworld.title: Billiard Table
realworld.description: Hard billiard balls undergo collisions that are very nearly elastic, preserving kinetic energy and allowing for predictable bank shots.

realworld.title: Car Crash
realworld.description: When cars crumple and lock together during a crash, they move as one unit, representing a nearly perfectly inelastic collision with maximum energy dissipation as deformation.

Physics.chapterName: Motion of System of Particles and Rigid Body
Physics.title: Unit 5: System of Particles and Rigid Body

notes.title: Understanding Centre of Mass
points: The centre of mass (COM) is the weighted average position of all the mass in a system.
For a system of particles, it's the point where the entire mass of the system can be assumed to be concentrated.
In a uniform gravitational field, the centre of mass coincides with the centre of gravity.
The motion of the COM is not affected by internal forces within the system.

notes.title: Key Properties
points: The COM moves as if all external forces were applied at that point.
For a symmetric object with uniform density, the COM is at the geometric center.
The COM may lie outside the physical boundaries of the object (e.g., a ring or a boomerang).
The concept is crucial in analyzing the motion of complex systems and rigid bodies.

formulas.title: COM for Discrete System (x-coordinate)
formulas.explanation: The x-coordinate of the center of mass for a system of particles, where m_i is the mass of the ith particle and x_i is its x-coordinate.

formulas.title: COM for Continuous Mass Distribution
formulas.explanation: The position vector of the center of mass for a continuous mass distribution, where M is the total mass and r is the position vector of the mass element dm.

formulas.title: COM of Two-Particle System
formulas.explanation: The x-coordinate of the center of mass for a two-particle system, where m₁ and m₂ are the masses, and x₁ and x₂ are their respective positions.

realworld.title: Balancing a Seesaw
realworld.description: A seesaw balances when the center of mass is directly above the pivot point. Heavier objects must be closer to the pivot to balance lighter objects further away.

realworld.title: High Jump Technique
realworld.description: High jumpers use the Fosbury Flop technique to curve their bodies, allowing their center of mass to pass under the bar while their body goes over it.

realworld.title: Stability of Vehicles
realworld.description: SUVs have a higher center of mass compared to regular cars, making them more prone to rollovers during sharp turns at high speeds.

realworld.title: Diving and Gymnastics
realworld.description: Divers and gymnasts tuck their bodies to change their moment of inertia, allowing them to rotate faster while their center of mass follows a parabolic trajectory.

notes.title: Fundamental Concepts
points: The center of mass (COM) of a system moves as if all external forces were applied at that point.
Internal forces between particles do not affect the motion of the COM.
The COM moves with constant velocity when no external force acts on the system.
For an isolated system, the total linear momentum of the COM remains constant.

notes.title: Key Principles
points: The acceleration of the COM is determined by the net external force divided by the total mass.
In the absence of external forces, the COM remains at rest or moves with constant velocity (Newton's First Law).
The motion of the COM is independent of the internal motions of the system's particles.
The COM frame of reference is particularly useful for analyzing collisions and explosions.

formulas.title: Velocity of COM
formulas.explanation: The velocity of the center of mass, where m_i and v_i are the mass and velocity of the ith particle, and M is the total mass.

formulas.title: Acceleration of COM
formulas.explanation: The acceleration of the center of mass equals the net external force divided by the total mass of the system.

formulas.title: Momentum of COM
formulas.explanation: The total linear momentum of the system equals the product of the total mass and the velocity of the COM.

realworld.title: Rocket Propulsion
realworld.description: As a rocket burns fuel and ejects exhaust gases, the COM of the rocket-exhaust system continues to move according to the net external force, while the rocket itself accelerates forward.

realworld.title: Exploding Firework
realworld.description: When a firework explodes in mid-air, the fragments move in different directions, but their center of mass continues to follow the original parabolic trajectory (neglecting air resistance).

realworld.title: High Jump Technique
realworld.description: In the Fosbury Flop technique, the jumper's COM actually passes below the bar while the body goes over it, demonstrating how the COM's motion can be manipulated relative to the body's motion.

realworld.title: Colliding Cars
realworld.description: In a car collision, the center of mass of the two-car system continues to move forward with the same velocity it had before the collision (assuming no external horizontal forces), regardless of how the cars crumple together.

notes.title: Conservation and Motion
points: The total linear momentum of a system of particles is equal to the product of the total mass and the velocity of its center of mass.
Newton's Second Law for a system: The rate of change of total momentum is equal to the net external force.
Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum: If the net external force is zero, the total linear momentum of the system remains constant.
This principle applies even if internal forces are very complex, such as in explosions or collisions.

formulas.title: Total Momentum
formulas.explanation: Total momentum is total mass times velocity of center of mass.

realworld.title: Recoil of a Gun
realworld.description: When a bullet is fired, the gun recoils backwards with a momentum equal and opposite to that of the bullet to keep the system's total momentum constant.

notes.title: Fundamental Concepts
points: Motion of a rigid body where every point moves in a circle about a common fixed axis.
In pure rotation, the axis of rotation is fixed and points on the axis have zero velocity.
Kinematics of rotation involves angular variables like theta, omega, and alpha.
Relationship between linear and angular variables: v = rω and a = rα.

formulas.title: Linear-Angular Velocity
formulas.explanation: v is the linear velocity, ω is the angular velocity, and r is the position vector from the axis.

realworld.title: Ceiling Fan
realworld.description: The blades of a fan rotate around a central motor shaft, where points further from the center move with higher linear speed despite having the same angular velocity.

notes.title: Angular Kinematics
points: Angular Displacement (θ): Angle swept by the radius vector (measured in radians).
Angular Velocity (ω): Time rate of change of angular displacement.
Angular Acceleration (α): Time rate of change of angular velocity.
Equations of rotational motion are similar to linear motion for constant α.

formulas.title: Equations of Rotation
formulas.explanation: Final angular velocity equals initial angular velocity plus angular acceleration times time.

formulas.title: Angular Displacement Formula
formulas.explanation: Analogous to s = ut + ½at² in linear motion.

realworld.title: Car Wheels
realworld.description: When a car speeds up, its wheels undergo angular acceleration, increasing their rotation rate per minute (RPM).

notes.title: Rotational Inertia
points: Moment of inertia (I) is the rotational analogue of mass; it measures a body's resistance to change in its rotational motion.
Depends on the mass of the body, its shape, size, and the distribution of mass relative to the axis of rotation.
Radius of Gyration (k): The distance from the axis where the entire mass can be assumed to be concentrated to give the same I.
Parallel Axis Theorem: I = I_cm + Md².
Perpendicular Axis Theorem: I_z = I_x + I_y (for laminar bodies).

formulas.title: Moment of Inertia (Discrete)
formulas.explanation: Sum of mass times square of distance from the axis for all particles.

formulas.title: Radius of Gyration
formulas.explanation: I is moment of inertia, M is total mass, and k is radius of gyration.

realworld.title: Flywheels
realworld.description: Engine flywheels have large moments of inertia to resist changes in speed, helping to smooth out the power output from engine pulses.

realworld.title: Figure Skater Spin
realworld.description: A skater spins faster by pulling their arms in, which decreases their moment of inertia relative to the rotation axis.

notes.title: Rotational Dynamics
points: Torque (τ): The turning effect of a force. Moment of force τ = r × F.
Angular Momentum (L): Rotational analogue of linear momentum L = r × p.
Relationship τ = dL/dt: Net torque equals rate of change of angular momentum.
L = Iω for a rigid body rotating about a fixed axis.

formulas.title: Torque Formula
formulas.explanation: Torque equals force times perpendicular distance, or moment of inertia times angular acceleration.

formulas.title: Angular Momentum
formulas.explanation: Product of moment of inertia and angular velocity.

realworld.title: Opening a Door
realworld.description: It is easier to open a door by pushing on the handle furthest from the hinges because it provides a larger 'r' (lever arm), resulting in more torque.

notes.title: Conservation Principle
points: If the net external torque acting on a system is zero, the total angular momentum of the system remains constant.
If I changes, ω must change such that Iω = constant.
Crucial in planetary motion and stellar evolution (e.g., formation of pulsars).

formulas.title: Conservation Law
formulas.explanation: Initial angular momentum equals final angular momentum when τ_ext = 0.

realworld.title: Ice Skater Tucking
realworld.description: When an ice skater pulls their arms in (decreasing I), their angular velocity (ω) increases significantly to conserve angular momentum.

realworld.title: Diver Somersaults
realworld.description: A diver tucks their body to decrease moment of inertia and increase their rotation rate before entering the water.

notes.title: Combined Motion
points: Rolling is a combination of translational motion of the center of mass and rotational motion about the center of mass.
Pure Rolling: Point of contact with the ground is at rest relative to the surface (v_cm = Rω).
Total Kinetic Energy: K = ½Mv_cm² + ½I_cmω².
Static friction is responsible for pure rolling on an inclined plane.

formulas.title: Total Kinetic Energy
formulas.explanation: k is radius of gyration, R is radius of the object, M is mass, and v is velocity of center of mass.

realworld.title: Bowling Ball
realworld.description: A bowling ball starts by sliding and eventually transitions into pure rolling as friction acts to equate v_cm and Rω.

notes.title: Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation
points: Every particle in the universe attracts every other particle with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
The force acts along the line joining the centers of the two masses.
It is a conservative force, meaning the work done by gravity depends only on initial and final positions, not the path taken.
The gravitational force is always attractive in nature.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: The law is called 'universal' because it applies to all objects with mass, from subatomic particles to galaxies.
Gravitational force is the weakest of the four fundamental forces but has an infinite range.
The force follows the inverse-square law, meaning it decreases with the square of the distance between masses.
The principle of superposition states that the net gravitational force on a particle is the vector sum of forces from all other particles.

formulas.title: Universal Law of Gravitation
formulas.explanation: F is the gravitational force between two masses m₁ and m₂, r is the distance between their centers, and G is the gravitational constant (6.674 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²).

formulas.title: Gravitational Field Strength
formulas.explanation: The gravitational field strength (g) at a point is the force per unit mass experienced by a small test mass placed at that point.

formulas.title: Gravitational Force Between Two Spheres
formulas.explanation: For two uniform spheres, the gravitational force acts as if all their mass were concentrated at their centers, with r being the distance between centers.

realworld.title: Earth's Orbit Around the Sun
realworld.description: The Earth's nearly circular orbit around the Sun is maintained by the gravitational force, which provides the necessary centripetal force to keep Earth in orbit.

realworld.title: Tides in Oceans
realworld.description: The Moon's gravitational pull creates bulges in Earth's oceans, causing high and low tides. The Sun's gravity also affects tides, though to a lesser extent due to its greater distance.

realworld.title: Artificial Satellites
realworld.description: Satellites in Earth's orbit are kept in place by the balance between Earth's gravitational pull and their tangential velocity, demonstrating practical applications of gravitational principles.

realworld.title: Black Holes
realworld.description: Black holes are regions of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape, representing an extreme consequence of gravitational theory.

notes.title: Understanding 'g'
points: Acceleration due to gravity (g) is the acceleration of an object due to Earth's gravitational pull.
Near Earth's surface, g ≈ 9.8 m/s² (standard value), but it varies with location and altitude.
It's a vector quantity, always directed towards the center of the Earth.
The value of g decreases with height above the Earth's surface and depth below it.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: g is independent of the mass of the falling object (Galileo's law of falling bodies).
In the absence of air resistance, all objects fall with the same acceleration.
The value of g is maximum at the poles and minimum at the equator.
g decreases with rotation of Earth, being zero at the equator if Earth rotated 17 times faster.

formulas.title: Acceleration due to Gravity
formulas.explanation: g is the acceleration due to gravity, G is the gravitational constant, M is Earth's mass, and R is Earth's radius.

formulas.title: g at Height h
formulas.explanation: The value of g at height h above Earth's surface, where R is Earth's radius. The approximation is valid when h << R.

formulas.title: g at Depth d
formulas.explanation: The value of g at depth d below Earth's surface, where R is Earth's radius. At Earth's center (d = R), g becomes zero.

realworld.title: Weightlessness in Space
realworld.description: Astronauts in orbit experience weightlessness not because there's no gravity (g is about 90% of surface value in low Earth orbit), but because they're in continuous free fall around Earth.

realworld.title: Pendulum Clocks
realworld.description: The period of a simple pendulum depends on g (T = 2π√(L/g)), so pendulum clocks must be readjusted when moved to locations with different g values, such as from sea level to a mountain.

realworld.title: Gravitational Time Dilation
realworld.description: Clocks run slower in stronger gravitational fields. GPS satellites must account for this effect, as their clocks run faster in orbit than on Earth's surface.

realworld.title: Ocean Tides
realworld.description: The Moon's gravitational pull creates a tidal bulge because it's stronger on the side of Earth nearest the Moon than on the far side, causing two high tides each day.

topics.name: Variation of g with Altitude and Depth

notes.title: Altitude (Height h)
points: g decreases as we go up from Earth's surface.
Formula: gh = g(1 - 2h/R) for h << R.

notes.title: Depth (d)
points: g decreases as we go down into Earth.
Formula: gd = g(1 - d/R).
At Earth's center (d=R), g is zero.

notes.title: Shape and Rotation
points: g is max at poles (R is min) and min at equator (R is max).
Earth's rotation reduces g at the equator due to centrifugal force.

realworld.title: Mountaineering
realworld.description: Weight decreases slightly at the top of Mount Everest due to increased altitude, although the difference is very small.

realworld.title: Mining
realworld.description: Gravity is slightly different in deep mines compared to the surface, affecting precise pendulum measurements.

notes.title: Definition
points: Work done in bringing a mass from infinity to a point in the gravitational field.
Always negative because gravitational force is attractive.
Maximum (zero) at infinity.

formulas.title: Gravitational Potential Energy
formulas.explanation: Potential energy of a two-particle system separated by distance r.

formulas.title: Gravitational Potential
formulas.explanation: Potential energy per unit mass.

realworld.title: Hydroelectric Dams
realworld.description: Water stored at a height possesses gravitational potential energy, which is converted into kinetic energy to generate electricity.

notes.title: Concept
points: Minimum velocity required for an object to escape the gravitational influence of a planet.
For Earth, ve ≈ 11.2 km/s.
Independent of the mass of the escaping object.

formulas.title: Escape Velocity
formulas.explanation: Escape velocity from the surface of a planet of mass M and radius R.

formulas.title: Relation with Orbital Velocity
formulas.explanation: Escape velocity is √2 times the orbital velocity near the surface.

realworld.title: Atmosphere Retention
realworld.description: The Moon has no atmosphere because the thermal speed of gas molecules exceeds the Moon's low escape velocity (2.4 km/s).

realworld.title: Rocket Launch
realworld.description: Interplanetary missions must reach escape velocity to break free from Earth's gravity and travel to other planets.

notes.title: Satellite Motion
points: Velocity required for a satellite to revolve around a planet in a stable orbit.
Independent of the mass of the satellite.
Decreases as the radius of the orbit increases.

formulas.title: Orbital Velocity
formulas.explanation: Velocity of a satellite orbiting at distance r from center of Earth.

formulas.title: Time Period
formulas.explanation: Time taken to complete one revolution.

realworld.title: Geostationary Satellites
realworld.description: Satellites with an orbital period of 24 hours appear stationary relative to Earth, used for telecommunications and weather forecasting.

notes.title: Three Laws
points: 1. Law of Orbits: All planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun at one of the foci.
2. Law of Areas: The line joining the Sun and the planet sweeps out equal areas in equal intervals of time (Areal velocity is constant). Conservation of angular momentum.
3. Law of Periods: The square of the time period of revolution (T) is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis (a) of the ellipse (T² ∝ a³).

formulas.title: Third Law
formulas.explanation: Square of period is proportional to cube of semi-major axis.

realworld.title: Comet Orbits
realworld.description: Comets like Halley's Comet have highly elliptical orbits, speeding up significantly when near the Sun (Law of Areas) and slowing down when far away.

notes.title: Fundamentals of Elasticity
points: Elasticity is the property of a material to regain its original shape and size after the removal of deforming force.
Elastic behavior is observed up to a certain limit called the elastic limit.
Perfectly elastic bodies return to their original state completely after the deforming force is removed.
Plasticity is the property of a material to retain its deformed shape even after the removal of deforming force.

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: Elastic Moduli are constants that measure a material's resistance to deformation.
The three main types of elastic moduli are Young's modulus, shear modulus, and bulk modulus.
Elastic fatigue occurs when a material is subjected to repeated stress cycles below the elastic limit.
Elastic hysteresis is the energy lost as heat when a material is loaded and unloaded.

formulas.title: Young's Modulus (Y)
formulas.explanation: Measures the stiffness of a solid material, where F is the force applied, A is the cross-sectional area, ΔL is the change in length, and L₀ is the original length.

formulas.title: Shear Modulus (G)
formulas.explanation: Measures the material's response to shear stress, where θ is the shear strain (angle of deformation).

formulas.title: Bulk Modulus (K)
formulas.explanation: Measures a substance's resistance to uniform compression, where ΔP is the change in pressure and ΔV/V is the relative volume change.

realworld.title: Rubber Bands
realworld.description: Rubber bands can stretch significantly and return to their original shape, demonstrating high elasticity due to their polymer chain structure.

realworld.title: Steel vs. Rubber
realworld.description: Steel is more elastic than rubber because it can withstand greater stress before permanent deformation, despite rubber being more stretchable.

realworld.title: Bungee Jumping Cords
realworld.description: Bungee cords are designed with specific elastic properties to safely absorb and return the kinetic energy of a falling jumper.

realworld.title: Car Suspension Systems
realworld.description: Springs in car suspensions use the elastic properties of metal to absorb shocks and provide a smooth ride by temporarily storing and releasing mechanical energy.

notes.title: Definitions
points: Stress: Internal restoring force per unit area. Types: Tensile, Compressive, Tangential (Shear).
Strain: Change in dimension per unit original dimension. It is dimensionless.
Hooke's Law: Within elastic limit, stress is directly proportional to strain.
Stress-Strain Curve: Shows proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, and permanent set.

formulas.title: Stress Formula
formulas.explanation: Normal force divided by the area of cross-section.

realworld.title: Structural Engineering
realworld.description: Architects calculate the stress on support beams to ensure they don't reach the yield point under the weight of a building.

notes.title: Fluid Statics
points: Pressure is force per unit area exerted perpendicular to a surface.
Pascal's Law: Pressure applied to an enclosed fluid is transmitted undiminished to every part of the fluid.
Atmospheric Pressure: Pressure exerted by the weight of air in the atmosphere.
Variation with depth: Pressure increases linearly with depth in a static fluid.

formulas.title: Pressure at Depth
formulas.explanation: P₀ is atmospheric pressure, h is depth, ρ is density of fluid, and g is acceleration due to gravity.

realworld.title: Hydraulic Brakes
realworld.description: A small force on the brake pedal is transmitted through fluid to generate a large force on the brake pads, stopping the wheels.

realworld.title: Submarines
realworld.description: Submarine hulls are built thick to withstand the massive pressure at great sea depths.

notes.title: Fluid Dynamics
points: Viscosity: Internal friction in a fluid that resists flow.
Coefficient of Viscosity (η) decreases for liquids with temperature and increases for gases.
Stokes' Law: Describes frictional force on an object moving through a viscous fluid.
Surface Tension: Tendency of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible.
Capillarity: Rise or fall of a liquid in a narrow tube due to surface tension.

formulas.title: Terminal Velocity
formulas.explanation: The constant speed reached by a body falling through a viscous fluid.

formulas.title: Surface Tension
formulas.explanation: Force per unit length acting perpendicular to a line on the liquid surface.

realworld.title: Engine Oil
realworld.description: Motor oil is categorized by viscosity (SAE numbers) to ensure it lubricates engine parts effectively at high operating temperatures.

realworld.title: Water Striders
realworld.description: Insects can walk on water because their weight is balanced by the surface tension of the water surface acting like an elastic sheet.

notes.title: Thermal Equilibrium Basics
points: Thermal equilibrium occurs when two objects in thermal contact no longer exchange heat, reaching the same temperature.
At thermal equilibrium, the macroscopic properties of the system become constant over time.
The concept is fundamental to the definition of temperature and the zeroth law of thermodynamics.
Thermal equilibrium is a dynamic equilibrium where microscopic energy exchange continues but with no net energy transfer.

notes.title: Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
points: If two systems are each in thermal equilibrium with a third system, they are in thermal equilibrium with each other.
The law establishes temperature as a fundamental and measurable property of thermodynamic systems.
It justifies the use of thermometers to measure temperature consistently.
The law was formulated after the first and second laws but was considered so fundamental that it was called the 'zeroth' law.

formulas.title: Zeroth Law Statement
formulas.formula: If A = B and B = C, then A = C
formulas.explanation: If system A is in thermal equilibrium with system B, and system B is in thermal equilibrium with system C, then system A is in thermal equilibrium with system C.

formulas.title: Thermal Expansion (Linear)
formulas.explanation: The change in length (ΔL) of a material is proportional to its original length (L₀), the temperature change (ΔT), and the coefficient of linear expansion (α).

formulas.title: Thermal Expansion (Volume)
formulas.explanation: The change in volume (ΔV) is proportional to the original volume (V₀), temperature change (ΔT), and the coefficient of volume expansion (β ≈ 3α for isotropic materials).

realworld.title: Thermometer Calibration
realworld.description: Thermometers work based on the zeroth law - when a thermometer reaches thermal equilibrium with a substance, they share the same temperature, allowing accurate temperature measurement.

realworld.title: Bimetallic Strips
realworld.description: Used in thermostats, bimetallic strips bend when heated due to different thermal expansion coefficients of the two metals, demonstrating thermal equilibrium principles.

realworld.title: Thermal Expansion Joints in Bridges
realworld.description: Bridges have expansion joints to accommodate length changes due to temperature variations, preventing structural damage as the bridge reaches thermal equilibrium with its environment.

realworld.title: Hot Coffee Cooling
realworld.description: A hot cup of coffee left in a room will cool until it reaches thermal equilibrium with the surrounding air, demonstrating the natural tendency of systems to reach equilibrium.

notes.title: Fundamental Energy Concepts
points: Heat (Q): Energy in transit due to temperature difference.
Work (W): Energy transfer through mechanical means. w = -P.ΔV (expansion work).
Internal Energy (U): Total energy (KE + PE) of all molecules in a system.
U is a state function; Q and W are path functions.

formulas.title: Specific Heat Capacity
formulas.explanation: Heat required to raise temperature of unit mass by unit degree.

formulas.title: Molar Heat Capacity
formulas.explanation: Heat capacity per mole of substance.

realworld.title: Calorimetry
realworld.description: Used in nutrition to determine the caloric content of food by burning it and measuring the temperature change in water.

notes.title: Conservation of Energy
points: ΔU = Q + W (IUPAC convention).
Isothermal Process: Temperature remains constant (ΔU = 0).
Adiabatic Process: No heat exchange (Q = 0).
Isobaric: Constant Pressure. Isochoric: Constant Volume.

formulas.title: Adiabatic Equation
formulas.explanation: Relation for an adiabatic process, where γ is the ratio of molar heat capacities.

realworld.title: Diesel Engines
realworld.description: Rapid compression of air in a diesel engine cylinder raises its temperature significantly (adiabatic heating), causing the fuel to ignite without a spark plug.

notes.title: Limits of Heat Conversion
points: Kelvin-Planck Statement: Impossible to convert all heat from a reservoir into work.
Clausius Statement: Heat cannot flow from cold to hot spontaneously.
Reversible process: Can be retraced in the opposite direction without any change in the universe.
Carnot Cycle: Idealized reversible cycle providing maximum theoretical efficiency.

formulas.title: Carnot Efficiency
formulas.explanation: Maximum possible efficiency for a heat engine operating between two temperatures (in Kelvin).

realworld.title: Steam Turbines
realworld.description: Power plants use high-temperature steam to maximize the efficiency of turbines based on the Carnot principle.

notes.title: Basic Molecular Concepts
points: All matter is composed of tiny particles called atoms or molecules that are in constant motion.
In solids, particles are closely packed in a fixed arrangement with strong intermolecular forces.
In liquids, particles are close but can move past one another with moderate intermolecular forces.
In gases, particles are far apart with negligible intermolecular forces, moving freely in all directions.

notes.title: Molecular Behavior in Gases
points: Gas molecules move randomly in straight lines until they collide with each other or container walls.
Molecular collisions are perfectly elastic (no loss of kinetic energy).
The average kinetic energy of gas molecules is directly proportional to the absolute temperature.
Intermolecular forces are negligible except during collisions.

formulas.title: Average Kinetic Energy per Molecule
formulas.explanation: The average translational kinetic energy of a gas molecule, where k_B is the Boltzmann constant (1.38 × 10⁻²³ J/K) and T is the absolute temperature in Kelvin.

formulas.title: Root Mean Square Speed
formulas.explanation: The square root of the average of the squares of the molecular speeds, where R is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol·K), T is temperature in Kelvin, and M is the molar mass in kg/mol.

formulas.title: Most Probable Speed
formulas.explanation: The speed at which the maximum number of molecules are moving at a given temperature.

realworld.title: Perfume Diffusion
realworld.description: When perfume is sprayed in a room, its molecules move randomly and collide with air molecules, eventually spreading throughout the space, demonstrating the continuous random motion of molecules.

realworld.title: Tire Pressure in Different Seasons
realworld.description: Car tire pressure decreases in winter because lower temperatures reduce the average kinetic energy of air molecules, decreasing the force of their collisions with the tire walls.

realworld.title: Hot Air Balloons
realworld.description: Heating air in a balloon increases the average speed of air molecules, causing them to spread out and decrease the air density inside the balloon, making it rise.

realworld.title: Pressure Cookers
realworld.description: In a pressure cooker, increasing temperature raises the speed of water vapor molecules, increasing the frequency and force of their collisions with the container walls, thus increasing pressure.

notes.title: Standard Assumptions
points: Gas consists of identical molecules, behaving as point masses.
Molecules are in continuous random motion.
The actual volume of molecules is negligible compared to the gas volume.
No attractive forces between molecules (except during collision).
Time of collision is much smaller than time between collisions.

formulas.title: Ideal Gas Pressure
formulas.explanation: M is total mass of gas, V is volume, and <v²> is mean square speed.

realworld.title: Pneumatic Tools
realworld.description: Compressed air tools use the high-frequency collisions of air molecules to drive hammers and wrenches.

notes.title: Energy Distribution
points: Degrees of Freedom (f): Number of independent coordinates required to specify the motion of a molecule.
Monoatomic (f=3), Diatomic (f=5 at low T, 7 at high T), Polyatomic (f=6).
Law of Equipartition: Average energy associated with each degree of freedom is ½k_BT.

formulas.title: Mean Energy of Molecule
formulas.explanation: Total average energy of a molecule with f degrees of freedom.

realworld.title: Infrared Thermography
realworld.description: Thermal cameras detect the vibrational energy of molecules as infrared radiation to map heat distribution.

notes.title: Mayer's Relation
points: Cₚ: Specific heat at constant pressure. Cᵥ: Specific heat at constant volume.
Cₚ is always greater than Cᵥ because work is done in expansion at constant pressure.
Ratio γ = Cₚ / Cᵥ depends on degrees of freedom (γ = 1 + 2/f).

formulas.title: Mayer's Formula
formulas.explanation: Universal relationship for an ideal gas constant R.

realworld.title: Global Warming
realworld.description: Greenhouse gases like CO₂ have higher degrees of freedom and heat capacities, trapping more thermal energy in the atmosphere.

notes.title: Molecular Travel
points: The average distance traveled by a molecule between two successive collisions.
It is inversely proportional to the density and square of the molecular diameter.
Explains why diffusion in gases is not instantaneous.

formulas.title: Mean Free Path
formulas.explanation: n is number density and d is the diameter of the gas molecule.

realworld.title: Vacuum Chambers
realworld.description: In high-vacuum systems, the mean free path can be hundreds of meters, allowing particles to travel without hitting anything.

notes.title: Definitions and Types
points: Periodic Motion: Motion that repeats itself at regular intervals of time (e.g., Earth's revolution).
Oscillatory Motion: To and fro motion of a body about a mean position (e.g., motion of a swing).
All oscillatory motions are periodic, but not all periodic motions are oscillatory.
Equilibrium Position: The position where the net force on the object is zero.

formulas.title: Time Period and Frequency
formulas.explanation: T is the time period (seconds), and f is the frequency (Hertz).

realworld.title: Grandfather Clock
realworld.description: The swinging pendulum of a grandfather clock repeats its motion every second, maintaining a precise time period.

notes.title: Characteristics of SHM
points: A special type of oscillatory motion where acceleration is directly proportional to displacement and directed towards the mean position.
Phase: Describes the state of motion (position and direction) at any instant.
Energy in SHM: Total energy is conserved and is the sum of Kinetic Energy and Potential Energy.
Potential energy is maximum at extreme positions; Kinetic energy is maximum at the mean position.

formulas.title: Equation of SHM
formulas.explanation: x is displacement, A is amplitude, ω is angular frequency, and φ is the initial phase constant.

formulas.title: Total Energy in SHM
formulas.explanation: Total mechanical energy of a harmonic oscillator depends on the square of the amplitude.

realworld.title: Metronome
realworld.description: Musicians use metronomes that produce regular ticks based on the simple harmonic motion of an internal inverted pendulum.

notes.title: Spring-Mass Systems
points: Hooke's Law: Restoring force is proportional to extension (F = -kx).
Spring Constant (k): A measure of the stiffness of the spring.
Vertical Spring: The mean position shifts due to gravity, but the time period remains the same.
Combinations: Springs in series (1/k = 1/k1 + 1/k2) and parallel (k = k1 + k2).

formulas.title: Time Period of Spring
formulas.explanation: Time period depends on mass (m) and spring constant (k).

realworld.title: Car Suspension
realworld.description: Vehicle shock absorbers use heavy-duty springs designed with high spring constants to absorb sudden impacts from bumps.

notes.title: Ideal vs Practical Pendulum
points: Ideal Pendulum: A point mass suspended by a weightless, inextensible string from a frictionless support.
For small angles (θ < 15°), the motion is approximately simple harmonic.
Length of Pendulum: Distance from point of suspension to the center of gravity of the bob.
Second's Pendulum: A pendulum whose time period is exactly 2 seconds.

formulas.title: Time Period of Pendulum
formulas.explanation: l is the length of the pendulum and g is acceleration due to gravity.

realworld.title: Earth's Gravity Mapping
realworld.description: Precision pendulums can detect tiny variations in gravity (g) across different geographical locations.

notes.title: Fundamentals of Waves
points: Wave: A disturbance that transfers energy and momentum from one point to another without the actual transfer of matter.
Mechanical Waves: Require a medium (e.g., sound waves, water waves).
Electromagnetic Waves: Do not require a medium (e.g., light, radio waves).
Progressive Wave: A wave that travels continuously through a medium.

formulas.title: Wave Speed
formulas.explanation: v is speed, f is frequency, and λ is wavelength.

formulas.title: Wave Displacement
formulas.explanation: Equation of a plane progressive wave traveling in the +x direction.

realworld.title: Tsunami Waves
realworld.description: Tsunamis carry massive amounts of energy across thousands of miles of ocean through underwater seismic disturbances.

notes.title: Wave Classifications
points: Transverse Waves: Particles vibrate perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation (e.g., light, waves on a string).
Longitudinal Waves: Particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation (e.g., sound in air).
Sound wave speed in air depends on temperature and humidity.
Laplace's Correction: Newton's formula was corrected by including the adiabatic index (gamma) for gases.

formulas.title: Speed of Sound in Gas
formulas.explanation: γ is the adiabatic index, P is pressure, and ρ is density (Laplace's formula).

realworld.title: Earthquake Waves
realworld.description: Primary (P) waves are longitudinal and travel faster, while Secondary (S) waves are transverse and cause surface damage.

notes.title: Behavior of Sound
points: Reflection of Sound: Echoes and Reverberation.
Standing (Stationary) Waves: Formed by the superposition of two identical waves traveling in opposite directions.
Nodes: Points of zero displacement. Antinodes: Points of maximum displacement.
Beats: Periodic variations in loudness heard when two sound sources of slightly different frequencies interfere.

formulas.title: Beat Frequency
formulas.explanation: The number of beats per second is equal to the difference between the two frequencies.

formulas.title: Fundamental in Stretched String
formulas.explanation: f is fundamental frequency, L is length, T is tension, and μ is linear mass density.

realworld.title: Tuning a Guitar
realworld.description: Musicians listen for 'beats' between a reference fork and a string; when the beats disappear, the string is perfectly in tune.

notes.title: Frequency Shifts
points: The apparent change in frequency of a wave due to the relative motion between the source and the observer.
When moving towards each other, the apparent frequency increases (pitch becomes higher).
When moving away, the apparent frequency decreases (pitch becomes lower).
Applicable to both sound (acoustical) and light (optical) waves.

formulas.title: Apparent Frequency
formulas.explanation: v is speed of sound, v_o is velocity of observer, v_s is velocity of source.

realworld.title: Police Speed Radar
realworld.description: Radar guns emit radio waves and measure the frequency shift in the waves reflected off a moving car to calculate its speed.

Chemistry.title: Unit 1: Some Basic Concepts of Chemistry

notes.title: Fundamental Role of Chemistry
points: Chemistry is the branch of science that deals with the study of matter, its composition, structure, properties, and the changes it undergoes.
