formulas.title: Empirical Relationship
formulas.explanation: A useful approximation for moderately asymmetrical distributions.

realworld.title: Fashion and Inventory
realworld.description: Shoe manufacturers use the mode to determine which sizes are most common to ensure they stock enough of the most popular items.

topics.name: Measures of Dispersion: Range and Quartile Deviation

notes.title: What is Dispersion?
points: Dispersion measures the extent to which data points vary from the central value.
Two distributions can have the same mean but very different levels of spread.
Absolute measures (e.g., Range) give the spread in original units.
Relative measures (e.g., Coefficients) allow comparison between different datasets.

notes.title: Range and Inter-Quartile Range
points: Range is the simplest measure: Difference between the largest and smallest values.
Quartiles (Q₁, Q₂, Q₃) divide data into four equal parts.
Quartile Deviation is half of the inter-quartile range (Q₃ - Q₁)/2.
It is superior to Range as it ignores extreme values at the ends.

formulas.title: Range
formulas.explanation: The span between the maximum and minimum observations.

formulas.title: Quartile Deviation (Semi-Interquartile Range)
formulas.explanation: Measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data.

realworld.title: Weather Monitoring
realworld.description: Meteorologists report the daily temperature range (High - Low) to describe the climate volatility of a region.

notes.title: Understanding Mean Deviation
points: Mean Deviation (MD) is the arithmetic mean of the absolute values of deviations from a central value (Mean or Median).
It gives equal weight to all deviations.
We use absolute values (|x - A|) because the sum of actual deviations is zero.
MD from Median is usually smaller than MD from Mean.

formulas.title: MD for Ungrouped Data
formulas.explanation: Where A is the Mean or Median.

formulas.title: MD for Grouped Data
formulas.explanation: Frequency-weighted average of absolute deviations.

formulas.title: Coefficient of Mean Deviation
formulas.explanation: Relative measure used for comparing dispersion across distributions.

realworld.title: Investment Analysis
realworld.description: Financial analysts calculate MD to understand the average distance of stock returns from their historical average, measuring stability.

notes.title: The Gold Standard of Dispersion
points: Standard Deviation (SD) is the positive square root of the arithmetic mean of squares of deviations from the Mean.
Variance is the square of the Standard Deviation.
Squaring the deviations gives more weight to larger variations (outliers).
Unlike MD, SD is mathematically stable and used in advanced statistical tests.

formulas.title: Variance (Individual Series)
formulas.explanation: The average of squared differences from the Mean.

formulas.title: Standard Deviation (Short-cut Method)
formulas.explanation: Where dᵢ = xᵢ - A (assumed mean). Efficient for large numbers.

realworld.title: Quality Control in Manufacturing
realworld.description: Engineers aim for a low standard deviation in component sizes (e.g., screw diameters) to ensure every part fits perfectly in the assembly.

notes.title: Comparing Variability
points: CV is a relative measure of dispersion expressed as a percentage.
It is used to compare the consistency or stability of two or more datasets with different units or means.
A lower CV indicates higher consistency (more stable).
A higher CV indicates lower consistency (more variable/scattered).

formulas.title: Coefficient of Variation
formulas.explanation: Standard Deviation divided by Mean, expressed as a percent.

realworld.title: Stock Market Stability
realworld.description: Investors compare the CV of different assets (e.g., Gold vs. Tech Stocks) to see which one is more 'stable' relative to its average return.

notes.title: Relationship between Variables
points: Correlation measures the degree and direction of relationship between two variables.
Positive Correlation: Both variables move in the same direction.
Negative Correlation: Variables move in opposite directions.
Zero Correlation: No linear relationship exists.
Karl Pearson's Coefficient (r) ranges from -1 to +1.

notes.title: Spearman's Rank Correlation
points: Used when data is qualitative (e.g., beauty, intelligence) or cannot be measured precisely.
Relies on the ranks of observations rather than their actual values.
It is more robust against outliers than Pearson's coefficient.

formulas.title: Spearman's Rank Correlation Coefficient
formulas.explanation: Where d is the difference between ranks (R₁ - R₂) and n is the number of pairs.

notes.title: Moving Averages

4-yearly moving averages require 'centering' to align with the original time units.

notes.title: Introduction to Random Experiments
points: A random experiment is an experiment where the result cannot be predicted with certainty even when all conditions are kept identical.
The experiment must have more than one possible outcome.
It is impossible to predict the outcome in advance, but the set of all possible outcomes is known.
Examples include tossing a coin, throwing a die, or drawing a card from a deck.

notes.title: Outcomes
points: An outcome is a possible result of a random experiment.
For a coin toss, 'Heads' (H) and 'Tails' (T) are outcomes.
For a die roll, the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 are individual outcomes.
In the context of probability, outcomes are viewed as the most basic results that can be recorded.

notes.title: Deterministic vs. Random Experiments
points: Deterministic experiments result in the same outcome under identical conditions (e.g., adding two chemicals to get a known reaction).
Random experiments result in different outcomes under identical conditions (e.g., measuring the lifespan of a lightbulb).

realworld.title: Scientific Reliability
realworld.description: In high-precision scientific measurements, repeated trials often yield slightly different results due to random errors, behaving like a random experiment.

realworld.title: Quality Control
realworld.description: Factories test random units for defects, treating each test as a random experiment to estimate the overall failure rate.

notes.title: Defining Sample Space
points: The sample space (S) of a random experiment is the set of all possible outcomes.
Each element of S is called a sample point.
For a coin toss, S = {H, T}. For a die roll, S = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}.
The sample space must be exhaustive, meaning every possible outcome must be included.

notes.title: Representing Sample Space
points: Sample spaces can be represented using the roster method or set-builder notation.
When two coins are tossed, the sample space is S = {(H,H), (H,T), (T,H), (T,T)}.
Tree diagrams are often used to systematically list all outcomes in multi-stage experiments.
For rolling two dice, the sample space has 36 outcomes, usually represented as ordered pairs (x, y).

formulas.title: Total Outcomes for Multiple Trials
formulas.explanation: If an experiment with 'm' possible outcomes is repeated 'n' times, the total number of sample points is m^n. E.g., for 3 coins, 2^3 = 8.

realworld.title: Computer Science - Bit Strings
realworld.description: The set of all possible 8-bit strings (0s and 1s) forms a sample space of 2^8 = 256 outcomes, used in data encryption and coding theory.

realworld.title: Sports Brackets
realworld.description: In a tournament with 16 teams, the sample space of all possible winning paths is used to calculate the likelihood of a specific final matchup.

notes.title: Definition of an Event
points: An event (E) is any subset of the sample space S. (E ⊆ S).
An event is said to have occurred if the actual outcome of the experiment is one of the elements of E.
An event can be a single outcome or a collection of several outcomes.

notes.title: Important Types of Events
points: Impossible Event: An empty set (∅) containing no outcomes. Example: Rolling a 7 on a standard die.
Sure/Certain Event: The entire sample space S. Example: Rolling a number less than 7 on a die.
Simple/Elementary Event: An event that contains exactly one sample point. Example: Getting a 4 on a die.
Compound Event: An event that contains more than one sample point. Example: Getting an even number on a die {2, 4, 6}.

notes.title: Algebra of Events
points: Complementary Event (A'): The set of all outcomes in S that are NOT in A. Written as (S - A).
Event 'A or B' (A ∪ B): Outcomes belonging to A, or B, or both.
Event 'A and B' (A ∩ B): Outcomes belonging to both A and B.
Event 'A but not B' (A - B): Outcomes in A that are not in B.
Event 'Neither A nor B': Corresponding to (A ∪ B)' or A' ∩ B'.

realworld.title: Aviation Safety
realworld.description: Safety systems are designed to prevent the 'Impossible Event' of simultaneous failure of three redundant engines.

realworld.title: Public Health
realworld.description: If the probability of 'Infection' is p, the probability of 'No Infection' is 1-p, which is essential for herd immunity calculations.

notes.title: Mutually Exclusive Events
points: Two events A and B are mutually exclusive if they cannot occur at the same time (A ∩ B = ∅).
They are also called disjoint events.
Example: In a coin toss, 'Heads' and 'Tails' are mutually exclusive.
Example: In a deck of cards, drawing a 'Heart' and a 'Spade' on a single draw refers to mutually exclusive events.

notes.title: Exhaustive Events
points: Events E1, E2, ..., En are exhaustive if their union equals the sample space S (E1 ∪ E2 ∪ ... ∪ En = S).
Example: In a die roll, E1 = {1, 2, 3} and E2 = {4, 5, 6} are exhaustive.
Example: Selecting a student who is either a boy or a girl from a co-ed school is an exhaustive event.

formulas.title: Condition for Mutually Exclusive
formulas.explanation: If A and B are mutually exclusive, the probability of both occurring is zero.

realworld.title: Traffic Signals
realworld.description: Traffic lights are designed to be mutually exclusive; the Red, Green, and Yellow lights cannot be active for the same direction simultaneously.

realworld.title: Political Elections
realworld.description: In a simple two-party election, the possible outcomes (Win A, Win B, Tie) form an exhaustive set of events as they cover all possibilities.

notes.title: Probability Axioms
points: Axiom 1: For any event A, the probability P(A) is a non-negative real number (0 ≤ P(A) ≤ 1).
Axiom 2: The probability of the sure event S is 1, i.e., P(S) = 1.
Axiom 3: If A and B are mutually exclusive events, then P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B).
These axioms form the mathematical foundation for all modern probability theory.

notes.title: Equally Likely Outcomes
points: If all sample points are equally likely, the probability of an elementary event is 1/n, where n is the total number of outcomes.
Classical Probability: P(E) = (Number of outcomes favorable to E) / (Total number of possible outcomes).
This approach assumes 'equally likely' outcomes, which isn't always true for physical objects (like biased coins).

formulas.title: Classical Probability Formula
formulas.explanation: Used when all outcomes in the sample space are equally likely (e.g., a fair die).

formulas.title: Probability of Null Event
formulas.explanation: The probability of an impossible event is always zero.

realworld.title: Lotteries and Raffles
realworld.description: The probability of winning a lottery is calculated by dividing 1 by the total number of possible combinations, assuming each ticket has an equal chance.

realworld.title: Sports Betting Odds
realworld.description: Bookmakers use axiomatic probability to set odds that ensure they remain profitable regardless of the specific game outcome.

notes.title: Probability of 'A or B'
points: Calculates the likelihood that at least one of the two events A or B occurs (A ∪ B).
If A and B are NOT mutually exclusive, the intersection (A ∩ B) must be subtracted to avoid double counting.
The theorem is based on the principle of inclusion-exclusion.
Generalizes to three events: P(A ∪ B ∪ C).

formulas.title: Addition Theorem (2 Events)
formulas.formula: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ∩ B)
formulas.explanation: Valid for any two events. If Mutually Exclusive, P(A ∩ B) = 0.

formulas.title: Addition Theorem (3 Events)
formulas.formula: P(A ∪ B ∪ C) = P(A) + P(B) + P(C) - P(A ∩ B) - P(B ∩ C) - P(C ∩ A) + P(A ∩ B ∩ C)
formulas.explanation: Calculates the probability that at least one of three potentially overlapping events occurs.

realworld.title: Natural Disaster Planning
realworld.description: City planners calculate the probability of 'Floods' or 'Power Outages' occurring simultaneously using the addition theorem to prepare for extreme events.

realworld.title: Retail Marketing
realworld.description: Stores calculate the likelihood of a customer liking 'Brand A' or 'Brand B' to optimize stock, accounting for customers who like both.

notes.title: Probability of 'Not A'
points: The event A' (or ¬A) represents the non-occurrence of A.
The sum of probabilities of an event and its complement is always 1.
P(A) + P(A') = 1 implies P(at least one) = 1 - P(none).

notes.title: Odds in Favor and Against
points: Odds in favor of event A = P(A) : P(A').
Odds against event A = P(A') : P(A).
If an event has 3/10 probability, odds in favor are 3:7 and odds against are 7:3.

formulas.title: Complementary Probability
formulas.explanation: A powerful shortcut: it is often easier to calculate the probability of the complement and subtract from 1.

formulas.title: Odds in Favor to Probability
formulas.explanation: If the odds in favor are a : b, then the probability of the event is a/(a+b).

notes.title: Viruses
points: Non-cellular organisms characterized by having an inert crystalline structure outside the living cell.
Consist of genetic material (DNA or RNA) and a protein coat called a capsid made of capsomeres.
Obligate parasites that take over host cell machinery to replicate.
The name virus (means 'venom' or 'poisonous fluid') was given by Pasteur.
D.J. Ivanowsky (1892) recognized microbes causing tobacco mosaic disease.

notes.title: Viroids and Prions

Prions: Abnormally folded proteins that cause neurodegenerative diseases; similar in size to viruses but lack genetic material.
Prions cause BSE (Mad Cow Disease) in cattle and CJD in humans.

notes.title: Monocot Root (e.g., Maize)

Large and well-developed pith.
No secondary growth.

realworld.title: Orchid Roots
realworld.description: Epiphytic orchids have a specialized multi-layered epidermis called velamen to absorb moisture from the atmosphere.

topics.name: Anatomy of Dicot and Monocot Stem

notes.title: Dicot Stem
points: Vascular bundles arranged in a ring (Eustele).
Bundles are conjoint, collateral, and open (cambium present).
Definite distinction between cortex, endodermis, and pith.

notes.title: Monocot Stem
points: Vascular bundles are scattered in ground tissue (Atactostele).
Bundles are conjoint, collateral, and closed (no cambium).
Water containing cavities are present within bundles.

realworld.title: Corn Stalk Strength
realworld.description: Monocot stems like maize have a silica-reinforced sclerenchyma sheath around vascular bundles for strength against wind.

topics.name: Anatomy of Dicot and Monocot Leaf

notes.title: Dicot (Dorsiventral) Leaf
points: Mesophyll differentiated into palisade and spongy parenchyma.
Stomata generally more on the lower epidermis (hypostomatic).
Vascular bundles larger in the midrib.

notes.title: Monocot (Isobilateral) Leaf
points: Mesophyll not differentiated into layers.
Stomata present on both surfaces (amphistomatic).
Bulliform cells present in the upper epidermis to roll leaves during water stress.

formulas.title: Photosynthetic Efficiency
formulas.formula: η = (Energy stored in biomass / Solar energy absorbed) × 100
formulas.explanation: Often relates leaf anatomy (mesophyll density) to the plant's light-to-chemical energy conversion rate.

realworld.title: Grass Rolling
realworld.description: During dry weather, bulliform cells in grass leaves lose turgor, causing the leaf to roll and reduce water loss through transpiration.

notes.title: Vascular Cambium
points: Produces secondary xylem (wood) towards inside and secondary phloem towards outside.
Spring wood (Early): Larger vessels, lighter color; Autumn wood (Late): Narrower vessels, darker color.
Annual Rings: One spring wood + one autumn wood ring.

notes.title: Cork Cambium (Phellogen)
points: Produces phellem (cork) outside and phelloderm (secondary cortex) inside.
Bark consists of all tissues outside the vascular cambium.

notes.title: Heartwood and Sapwood
points: Heartwood: Central, non-functional, dark, durable (lignin/tannin deposits).
Sapwood: Peripheral, functional, light-colored, conducts water.

formulas.title: Tree Age (Dendrochronology)
formulas.explanation: Determining the age of a tree by counting the number of annual rings visible in a cross-section of the trunk.

realworld.title: Cork for Wine Bottles
realworld.description: Commercial cork is obtained from the thick bark (secondary phellem) of the Cork Oak (Quercus suber).

realworld.title: Termite Resistance
realworld.description: The tannins and oils in heartwood make it naturally resistant to decay and insect attacks, making it prized for furniture.

notes.title: Classification
points: Tissue: Group of cells having similar origin, structure, and function.
Four main types: Epithelial, Connective, Muscular, Neural.

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Covering or protective tissue.
Cells are compactly packed with little intercellular matrix.
Types: Simple (Single layer) and Compound (Multi-layered).

notes.title: Types of Simple Epithelium
points: Squamous: Flattened calls (Diffusion boundaries e.g., air sacs of lungs).
Cuboidal: Cube-like cells (Secretion and absorption e.g., kidney tubules).
Columnar: Tall cells (Absorption e.g., stomach, intestine).

realworld.title: Skin
realworld.description: The outer layer of our skin is made of compound epithelium (stratified squamous) which protects underlying tissues from mechanical stress and chemical burns.

notes.title: Function
points: Most abundant tissue.
Links and supports other tissues/organs.
Components: Cells, Fibers (Collagen, Elastin), Ground Substance.

notes.title: Types
points: Loose: Areolar, Adipose.
Dense: Tendons (Muscle to Bone), Ligaments (Bone to Bone).
Specialized: Cartilage, Bone, Blood.

realworld.title: Body Fat
realworld.description: Adipose tissue stores excess nutrients as fat and acts as an insulator to maintain body temperature.

realworld.title: Ear and Nose
realworld.description: The external ear (pinna) and the tip of the nose are made of flexible cartilage.

notes.title: Types
points: Skeletal (Striated/Voluntary): Attached to bones, multinucleated.
Smooth (Non-striated/Involuntary): Internal organs (e.g., stomach), uninucleated.
Cardiac: Heart muscle, branched, intercalated discs, involuntary.

realworld.title: Biceps
realworld.description: Flexing your arm involves the voluntary contraction of skeletal muscles like the biceps.

notes.title: Neuron
points: Functional unit of neural system.
Excitability: Ability to generate electrical impulses.
Neuroglial cells: Support and protect neurons.

realworld.title: Reflex Actions
realworld.description: The rapid withdrawal of a hand from a hot surface is a result of spinal reflex arcs composed of neural tissue.

notes.title: Principles
points: Schleiden and Schwann (1839): All living organisms are composed of cells and products of cells.
Rudolf Virchow (1855): 'Omnis cellula-e cellula' (New cells arise from pre-existing cells).

realworld.title: Tissue Engineering
realworld.description: Regenerative medicine relies on cell theory to grow new heart valves or skin grafts from a patient's own cells.

notes.title: Features
points: No membrane-bound nucleus (Nucleoid).
No membrane-bound organelles.
Examples: Bacteria, Blue-green algae, Mycoplasma.
Inclusions: Mesosome (infolding of membrane), Ribosomes (70S).

realworld.title: Antibiotics
realworld.description: Many antibiotics work by targeting specific features of prokaryotic cells (like cell wall synthesis or 70S ribosomes) without harming human eukaryotic cells.

notes.title: Features
points: Membrane-bound nucleus and organelles.
Compartmentalization of cytoplasm.
Examples: Protists, Fungi, Plants, Animals.
Plant vs Animal: Plants have Cell Wall, Plastids, and Large Vacuole. Animals have Centrioles.

realworld.title: Brewing and Baking
realworld.description: The use of yeast in industry is based on the metabolic processes of these single-celled eukaryotic organisms.

notes.title: Key Organelles
points: Mitochondria: Powerhouse of the cell (ATP production).
Chloroplast: Photosynthesis (in plants).
Ribosomes: Protein synthesis (80S in eukaryotes).
Endoplasmic Reticulum: RER (Protein synthesis), SER (Lipid synthesis).
Golgi Apparatus: Packaging and secretion.
Lysosome: Suicidal bag (Hydrolytic enzymes).
Nucleus: Controller of cell, contains genetic material.

realworld.title: Mitochondrial Diseases
realworld.description: Defects in mitochondria cause diseases affecting organs with high energy demand like the brain and muscles.

notes.title: Classification
points: Monosaccharides: Simple sugars (e.g., Glucose, Fructose, Ribose). General formula Cn(H2O)n.
Oligosaccharides: 2-10 monosaccharide units linked by glycosidic bonds (e.g., Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose).
Polysaccharides: Long chains (polymers) of monosaccharides (e.g., Starch, Cellulose, Glycogen).

formulas.title: General Formula
formulas.explanation: General formula for carbohydrates (hydrates of carbon).

realworld.title: Instant Energy
realworld.description: Athletes drink glucose water for instant energy because it is a simple sugar that is absorbed immediately into the bloodstream.

realworld.title: Paper and Cotton
realworld.description: Paper and cotton fibers are essentially pure cellulose, a structural polysaccharide found in plant cell walls.

notes.title: Structure
points: Polymers of amino acids linked by peptide bonds (-CONH-).
Primary Structure: Linear sequence of amino acids.
Secondary Structure: Hydrogen bonding leads to Alpha-helix or Beta-pleated sheet.
Tertiary Structure: 3D folding (essential for enzymatic function).
Quaternary Structure: Assembly of multiple polypeptide chains (e.g., Hemoglobin).

realworld.title: Hair and Nails
realworld.description: Keratin is a tough, fibrous structural protein that makes up hair, nails, and the outer layer of skin.

realworld.title: Egg White
realworld.description: Cooking an egg turns the transparent liquid white into a solid white mass because heat denatures (unfolds) the albumin protein.

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Water-insoluble organic compounds (Fats, Oils, Waxes).
Made of fatty acids and glycerol.
Saturated (Single bonds, solid at room temp) vs Unsaturated (Double bonds, liquid at room temp).

realworld.title: Blubber
realworld.description: Polar animals like whales and seals have a thick layer of fat (blubber) to insulate them against freezing water temperatures.

realworld.title: Soap
realworld.description: Soaps are sodium or potassium salts of fatty acids, made by reacting fats with strong bases.

notes.title: Components
points: Polymers of Nucleotides.
Nucleotide = Nitrogenous Base (Purines: A, G; Pyrimidines: C, T, U) + Pentose Sugar (Ribose/Deoxyribose) + Phosphate Group.
DNA: Genetic material, Double helix, A-T and G-C pairing.
RNA: Protein synthesis, Single stranded, A-U and G-C pairing.

realworld.title: DNA Fingerprinting
realworld.description: Forensic scientists use DNA characteristic patterns to identify individuals in criminal investigations.

notes.title: Properties
points: Biological catalysts (mostly proteins) that speed up reactions by lowering activation energy.
Highly specific (Lock and Key model or Induced Fit model).
Activity affected by Temperature (optimum ~37°C), pH, and Substrate concentration.

realworld.title: Bio-Detergents
realworld.description: Laundry detergents often contain enzymes like proteases and lipases to break down protein and fat-based stains effectively at lower temperatures.

realworld.title: Pineapple and Gelatin
realworld.description: Fresh pineapple contains bromelain (a protease) which breaks down gelatin proteins, preventing jelly from setting if fresh fruit is used.

Biology.title: Unit 10: Cell Cycle and Cell Division

notes.title: Interphase (Resting Phase)
points: G1 Phase: Cell growth, RNA/protein synthesis.
S Phase: DNA replication (amount doubles, chromosome number stays same), Centriole duplication.
G2 Phase: Preparation for mitosis, tubulin synthesis.
G0 Phase (Quiescent): Cells that do not divide further (e.g., heart cells).

realworld.title: Cancer
realworld.description: Cancer results from a loss of cell cycle regulation, leading to uncontrolled cell division and tumor formation.

notes.title: Equational Division
points: Prophase: Chromosomes condense, nuclear envelop disappears.
Metaphase: Chromosomes align at equator (Spindle fibers attach to kinetochores).
Anaphase: Centromeres split, chromatids move to opposite poles.
Telophase: Nuclear membrane reforms, chromosomes decondense.
Cytokinesis: Division of cytoplasm (Cell plate in plants, Furrow in animals).

realworld.title: Wound Healing
realworld.description: Skin cuts heal because surrounding cells undergo mitosis to replace the damaged tissue.

notes.title: Reductional Division
points: Occurs in gamete mother cells (germ cells).
Meiosis I: homologous chromosomes separate (Reductional). Prophase I has 5 stages: Leptotene, Zygotene (Synapsis), Pachytene (Crossing over), Diplotene (Chiasmata), Diakinesis.
Meiosis II: Sister chromatids separate (Equational).
Produces 4 haploid cells from 1 diploid cell.

realworld.title: Genetic Diversity
realworld.description: Crossing over during Meiosis I shuffles genes, leading to variation in offspring (why siblings don't look identical).

notes.title: Importance
points: Mitosis: Growth, repair, maintenance of genetic stability.
Meiosis: Gamete formation, maintaining chromosome number across generations, introducing variation.

notes.title: Diffusion
points: Movement of particles from high to low concentration.
Passive process, requires no energy.
Rate depends on concentration gradient, permeability, temperature, and pressure.

notes.title: Facilitated Diffusion
points: Movement of hydrophilic substances across the membrane using carrier proteins (Permeases).
Passive process, but specific and saturable.
Aquaporins: Water channels.

formulas.title: Water Potential
formulas.explanation: Water potential = Solute potential + Pressure potential.

realworld.title: Perfume Scent
realworld.description: Opening a perfume bottle releases scent molecules that diffuse through the air to fill the room.

notes.title: Pathways
points: Apoplast: Movement through cell walls and intercellular spaces (Non-living path). Continuous except at Casparian strips.
Symplast: Movement through cytoplasm and plasmodesmata (Living path).

realworld.title: Fresh Cut Flowers
realworld.description: Cutting stems under water prevents air bubbles from blocking xylem vessels, allowing continuous water absorption to keep flowers fresh.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Evaporative loss of water from aerial parts (Stomata).
Transpiration Pull: Cohesion-Tension theory explains ascent of sap.
Factors: Light, Temperature, Humidity, Wind speed.

realworld.title: Cooling Effect
realworld.description: Transpiration cools the leaf surface (similar to sweating in humans) and helps in temperature regulation.

notes.title: Phloem Transport
points: Source-Sink relationship: Leaves (Source) -> Roots/Fruits (Sink).
Mass Flow Hypothesis: Sucrose moves due to turgor pressure gradient.
Bidirectional transport (unlike unidirectional xylem flow).

realworld.title: Girdling Experiment
realworld.description: Removing a ring of bark (phloem) causes the stem above to swell due to food accumulation, proving phloem transports food.

notes.title: Criteria for Essentiality
points: The element must be absolutely necessary for supporting normal growth and reproduction.
The requirement of the element must be specific and not replaceable by another element.
The element must be directly involved in the metabolism of the plant.

realworld.title: Hydroponics
realworld.description: Plants are grown in nutrient solutions to identify essential elements and their deficiency symptoms.

notes.title: Classification
points: Macronutrients (>10 mmole/kg): C, H, O, N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S.
Micronutrients (<10 mmole/kg): Fe, Mn, Cu, Mo, Zn, B, Cl, Ni.

realworld.title: Fertilizers
realworld.description: NPK fertilizers are commonly used to supply Nitrogen, Phosphorus, and Potassium, the primary macronutrients.

notes.title: Common Symptoms
points: Chlorosis: Loss of chlorophyll (N, K, Mg, S, Fe, Mn, Zn, Mo).
Necrosis: Death of tissue (Ca, Mg, Cu, K).
Stunted Growth: Lack of N, K, S, Mo.

notes.title: Processes
points: Nitrogen Fixation: N2 -> NH3 (Biological: Rhizobium, Azotobacter).
Nitrification: NH3 -> NO2- -> NO3- (Nitrosomonas, Nitrobacter).
Ammonification: Organic N -> NH3.
Denitrification: NO3- -> N2 (Pseudomonas).

realworld.title: Leguminous Plants
realworld.description: Farmers rotate crops with legumes (peas, beans) to replenish soil nitrogen naturally through root nodules containing Rhizobium.

notes.title: Types
points: Chlorophyll a: Bright or blue-green; Primary pigment.
Chlorophyll b: Yellow-green; Accessory pigment.
Xanthophylls: Yellow.
Carotenoids: Yellow to yellow-orange.

realworld.title: Autumn Leaves
realworld.description: In autumn, chlorophyll breaks down, revealing the yellow/orange carotenoids and xanthophylls previously masked.

notes.title: Photochemical Phase
points: Occurs in Thylakoids (Grana).
Steps: Light absorption, water splitting (photolysis), oxygen release, formation of high-energy chemical intermediates (ATP and NADPH).
Z-Scheme: Non-cyclic electron transport involving PS II and PS I.

realworld.title: Solar Panels
realworld.description: Similar to how photosystems harvest light energy to generate electrons, solar panels convert sunlight into electrical energy.

notes.title: Biosynthetic Phase
points: Occurs in Stroma.
Does not directly depend on light but on products of light reaction (ATP, NADPH).
C3 Cycle (Calvin Cycle): First stable product is 3-PGA. Primary CO2 acceptor is RuBP. Enzyme: RuBisCO.

realworld.title: Greenhouses
realworld.description: Greenhouses often increase CO2 concentration to boost the rate of the dark reaction and consequently plant growth (yield).

notes.title: Limiting Factors
points: Law of Limiting Factors (Blackman): If a process is conditioned by multiple factors, its rate is limited by the slowest factor.
Factors: Light intensity, CO2 concentration, Temperature, Water.

realworld.title: Shade Plants
realworld.description: Indoor plants are adapted to photosynthesize efficiently even at lower light intensities compared to sun-loving crops.

notes.title: EMP Pathway
points: Occurs in Cytoplasm.
Anaerobic process (common to both aerobic and anaerobic respiration).
Breakdown of 1 Glucose (6C) into 2 Pyruvate (3C).
Net gain: 2 ATP and 2 NADH.

realworld.title: Muscle Cramps
realworld.description: In humans, lack of oxygen during heavy exercise leads to anaerobic breakdown of pyruvate into lactic acid, causing cramps.

notes.title: TCA Cycle / Citric Acid Cycle
points: Occurs in Mitochondrial Matrix.
Aerobic process.
Acetyl CoA (2C) enters the cycle.
Produces CO2, NADH, FADH2, and GTP.

notes.title: Oxidative Phosphorylation
points: Occurs in Inner Mitochondrial Membrane.
Electrons from NADH and FADH2 pass through complexes I-IV.
Proton gradient is created, driving ATP Synthase (Complex V) to produce ATP.
Oxygen acts as the final electron acceptor, forming metabolic water.

realworld.title: Cyanide Poisoning
realworld.description: Cyanide binds to Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV), blocking electron transport and stopping ATP production, leading to rapid death.

notes.title: Definition
points: Ratio of volume of CO2 evolved to volume of O2 consumed.
RQ = Vol CO2 / Vol O2.
RQ = 1 (Carbohydrates), <1 (Fats/Proteins), >1 (Organic acids).

formulas.title: RQ Formula
formulas.explanation: Measure of respiratory substrate.

notes.title: Stages
points: Meristematic: Rapid cell division, rich protoplasm.
Elongation: Vacuolation, cell enlargement.
Maturation: Cell differentiation and specialization.

formulas.title: Arithmetic Growth
formulas.explanation: Linear growth curve.

formulas.title: Geometric Growth
formulas.explanation: Sigmoid (S-shaped) growth curve.

realworld.title: Tree Rings
realworld.description: Annual rings in tree trunks represent periods of rapid growth (spring) and slow growth (autumn), used to determine age (Dendrochronology).

notes.title: PGRs
points: Auxins: Apical dominance, rooting.
Gibberellins: Stem elongation, bolting (in rosette plants).
Cytokinins: Cell division, delay senescence.
Ethylene: Fruit ripening (Gaseous hormone).
Abscisic Acid (ABA): Stress hormone, stomatal closure.

realworld.title: Artificial Ripening
realworld.description: Ethylene gas or ethephon is commercially used to ripen bananas and mangoes artificially for the market.

realworld.title: Weedicides
realworld.description: 2,4-D (a synthetic auxin) is widely used by farmers to kill broad-leaved weeds in cereal crops.

notes.title: Day Length Response
points: Response of plants to periods of day/night to initiate flowering.
Short Day Plants (SDP): Flower when night > critical duration (e.g., Chrysanthemum).
Long Day Plants (LDP): Flower when day > critical duration (e.g., Wheat).
Day Neutral Plants: No correlation (e.g., Tomato).

realworld.title: Floriculture
realworld.description: Greenhouses manipulate light duration to induce out-of-season flowering in commercial flowers.

notes.title: Cold Treatment
points: Induction of flowering by low temperature treatment.
Prevents precocious reproductive development late in the growing season.

realworld.title: Winter Wheat
realworld.description: Winter varieties of wheat are planted in autumn, pass through winter (cold treatment), and flower in spring.

notes.title: Alimentary Canal
points: Mouth: Teeth (Mastication) and Tongue (Deglutition).
Stomach: J-shaped organ; Gastric glands secrete HCl and Pepsinogen.
Small Intestine: Duodenum, Jejunum, Ileum. Main site of digestion and absorption.
Large Intestine: Caecum, Colon, Rectum. Absorbs water and minerals.

formulas.title: Dental Formula (Adult)
formulas.explanation: In each quadrant: 2 Incisors, 1 Canine, 2 Premolars, 3 Molars. Total 32 teeth.

realworld.title: Acid Reflux (Heartburn)
realworld.description: Regurgitation of acidic stomach contents into the esophagus causes a burning sensation, treated with antacids (bases).

realworld.title: Appendicitis
realworld.description: Inflammation of the vermiform appendix, a vestigial organ attached to the caecum, requiring surgical removal.

notes.title: Key Enzymes
points: Salivary Amylase (Ptyalin): Starch -> Maltose (pH 6.8).
Pepsin (Stomach): Proteins -> Peptones (pH 1.8).
Trypsin/Chymotrypsin (Pancreas): Proteins -> Dipeptides.
Lipase (Pancreas): Fats -> Fatty Acids + Glycerol (Emulsified by bile).

realworld.title: Lactose Intolerance
realworld.description: Lack of the enzyme lactase prevents digestion of milk sugar (lactose), leading to bloating and diarrhea.

notes.title: Mechanisms
points: Simple Diffusion: Glucose, amino acids (small amounts), chloride ions.
Facilitated Transport: Glucose, amino acids (with carrier proteins).
Active Transport: Against concentration gradient (e.g., Sodium ions).
Villi and Microvilli increase surface area for absorption in the small intestine.

realworld.title: ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution)
realworld.description: Adding glucose to salt water enhances the absorption of sodium and water in the intestine, crucial for treating dehydration/cholera.

Biology.title: Unit 17: Breathing and Exchange of Gases

notes.title: Pathway
points: Nostrils -> Nasal Chamber -> Pharynx -> Larynx (Voice Box) -> Trachea (Windpipe) -> Bronchi -> Bronchioles -> Alveoli.
Epiglottis prevents food from entering the larynx during swallowing.

notes.title: Lungs
points: Covered by double-layered pleura with pleural fluid (reduces friction).
Right lung has 3 lobes; Left lung has 2 lobes.

realworld.title: Choking
realworld.description: Talking while eating can cause the epiglottis to stay open, allowing food to enter the windpipe and trigger a coughing reflex.

notes.title: Inspiration (Active Process)
points: Diaphragm contracts (flattens) -> Increases thoracic volume antero-posteriorly.
External Intercostal Muscles contract -> Ribs moving up and out -> Increases thoracic volume dorso-ventrally.
Pulmonary pressure decreases < Atmospheric pressure -> Air rushes in.

notes.title: Expiration (Passive Process)
points: Diaphragm and Intercostal muscles relax -> Thoracic volume decreases.
Pulmonary pressure increases > Atmospheric pressure -> Air expelled.

formulas.title: Respiratory Rate
formulas.explanation: Normal breathing rate in a healthy adult.

realworld.title: Hiccups
realworld.description: Involuntary contraction (spasm) of the diaphragm followed by sudden closure of the vocal cords causes the 'hic' sound.

notes.title: Oxygen Transport
points: 97% transported by RBCs as Oxyhemoglobin.
3% dissolved in plasma.
Binding depends on pO2, pCO2, H+ conc, and temperature.

notes.title: Carbon Dioxide Transport
points: 20-25% as Carbamino-hemoglobin.
70% as Bicarbonate (HCO3-) in plasma (facilitated by Carbonic Anhydrase in RBCs).
7% dissolved in plasma.

realworld.title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
realworld.description: Hemoglobin has 200x higher affinity for CO than O2. CO binds irreversibly, preventing oxygen transport, which can be fatal.

notes.title: Neural Control
points: Respiratory Rhythm Centre (Medulla): Primary regulator.
Pneumotaxic Centre (Pons): Moderates function of rhythm centre (prevents over-inflation).
Chemosensitive Area: Highly sensitive to CO2 and H+ ions (not O2).

realworld.title: High Altitude
realworld.description: At high altitudes (low pO2), the body compensates by increasing breathing rate and RBC production (polycythemia).

notes.title: Composition of Blood
points: Plasma: Fluid matrix containing water (90-92%), proteins (fibrinogen, globulins, albumins), hormones, and nutrients.
Formed Elements: Erythrocytes (RBCs) transport O2/CO2; Leucocytes (WBCs) provide immunity; Thrombocytes (Platelets) help in clotting.

notes.title: Lymph (Tissue Fluid)
points: Colorless fluid containing lymphocytes.
Acts as a middleman for exchange of materials between blood and tissues.
Transports fats absorbed from the intestine (in lacteals).

realworld.title: Anemia
realworld.description: Low RBC count or hemoglobin leads to reduced oxygen transport, causing fatigue and paleness.

realworld.title: Blood Typing
realworld.description: Blood groups (A, B, AB, O) are determined by antigens on RBCs. Mismatched transfusions cause clumping (agglutination).

notes.title: Structure
points: Four-chambered muscular organ: Two Atria (upper) and Two Ventricles (lower).
Valves: Tricuspid (Right), Bicuspid/Mitral (Left), and Semilunar valves prevent backflow.
Double Circulation: Pulmonary (Lungs) and Systemic (Body) circulation.

notes.title: Conducting System
points: SAN (Sino-atrial node): 'Pacemaker' - initiates heartbeat.
AVN (Atrio-ventricular node), Bundle of His, Purkinje Fibers conduct the impulse.

realworld.title: Pacemaker Implant
realworld.description: When the natural pacemaker (SAN) fails, an electronic device is implanted to regulate the heartbeat.

notes.title: Phases
points: Joint Diastole: All chambers relaxed, blood fills atria and ventricles.
Atrial Systole: Atria contract, pushing remaining blood to ventricles.
Ventricular Systole: Ventricles contract, pumping blood to arteries (Pulmonary artery/Aorta); AV valves close ('Lub' sound).
Ventricular Diastole: Ventricles relax, semilunar valves close ('Dub' sound).

notes.title: Output
points: Stroke Volume: Volume pumped by each ventricle per beat (~70 ml).
Cardiac Output: Stroke Volume × Heart Rate (~5 L/min).

formulas.title: Cardiac Output
formulas.explanation: Cardiac Output = Stroke Volume × Heart Rate

realworld.title: Athletic Heart
realworld.description: Athletes have a lower resting heart rate because their heart pumps more blood per beat (higher stroke volume).

notes.title: Measurement
points: Pressure exerted by blood on arterial walls.
Systolic Pressure: 120 mmHg (Ventricular contraction).
Diastolic Pressure: 80 mmHg (Ventricular relaxation).
Measured using Sphygmomanometer.

realworld.title: Hypertension
realworld.description: Persistently high BP (>140/90) can damage vital organs like brain (stroke) and kidneys.

notes.title: Components
points: Kidneys: Bean-shaped organs responsible for filtering blood.
Ureters: Tubes carrying urine from kidneys to the bladder.
Urinary Bladder: Stores urine temporarily.
Urethra: Tube through which urine is expelled.

notes.title: Nephron
points: Functional unit of the kidney.
Parts: Glomerulus, Bowman's Capsule, PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule), Henle's Loop, DCT (Distal Convoluted Tubule), Collecting Duct.

realworld.title: Dialysis
realworld.description: Hemodialysis is used for patients with kidney failure to filter waste products like urea from the blood, mimicking the function of natural kidneys.

notes.title: Steps
points: Glomerular Filtration: Ultrafiltration of blood in the glomerulus.
Reabsorption: Useful substances (glucose, amino acids, water) are reabsorbed in PCT, Henle's loop, and DCT.
Secretion: Harmful substances (K+, H+, ammonia) are secreted into the filtrate.

realworld.title: Hydration and Urine Color
realworld.description: Dark yellow urine indicates dehydration (concentrated urine), while clear urine indicates good hydration (dilute urine), regulated by water reabsorption.

notes.title: Hormonal Control
points: ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone): Increases water reabsorption in DCT and collecting duct to prevent diuresis.
JGA (Juxtaglomerular Apparatus): Releases Renin when blood pressure falls (Renin-Angiotensin mechanism).
ANF (Atrial Natriuretic Factor): Vasodilator, opposes the Renin-Angiotensin system.

realworld.title: Alcohol and Dehydration
realworld.description: Alcohol inhibits ADH secretion, leading to excessive urination and subsequent dehydration (hangover).

notes.title: Cellular Movements
points: Amoeboid: Movement by pseudopodia (e.g., Macrophages, Leucocytes).
Ciliary: Movement by cilia (e.g., Trachea, Fallopian tubes).
Muscular: Movement by muscles (e.g., Limbs, Jaws).

notes.title: Divisions
points: Axial Skeleton (80 bones): Skull, Vertebral Column, Sternum, Ribs.
Appendicular Skeleton (126 bones): Limb bones (arms/legs) and Girdles (Pectoral/Pelvic).

notes.title: Joints
points: Fibrous (Immovable): e.g., Skull sutures.
Cartilaginous (Slightly movable): e.g., Between vertebrae.
Synovial (Freely movable): Ball & Socket, Hinge, Pivot, Gliding, Saddle.

realworld.title: Arthritis
realworld.description: Inflammation of joints causing pain and stiffness, common in old age.

realworld.title: Osteoporosis
realworld.description: Age-related disorder characterized by decreased bone mass and increased fracture risk, often due to low estrogen levels.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Sliding Filament Theory: Thin actin filaments slide over thick myosin filaments to shorten the sarcomere.
Role of Calcium: Ca++ binds to troponin, unmasking the active sites on actin for myosin binding.
Energy Source: ATP hydrolysis provides energy for the cross-bridge cycle.

realworld.title: Rigor Mortis
realworld.description: After death, muscles stiffen because ATP is depleted, preventing the detachment of myosin heads from actin.

realworld.title: Muscle Fatigue
realworld.description: Anaerobic respiration during strenuous exercise leads to accumulation of lactic acid, causing fatigue.

notes.title: Parts of a Neuron
points: Cell Body (aka Soma/Cyton): Contains nucleus and cytoplasm (neuroplasm).
Dendrites: Short, branched processes that receive impulses and transmit them towards the cell body.
Axon: Long fiber that transmits impulses away from the cell body to a synapse/neuromuscular junction.
Myelin Sheath: Fatty insulating layer around axon (Schwann cells), speeds up impulse transmission (Saltatory conduction).

realworld.title: Multiple Sclerosis
realworld.description: An autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks the myelin sheath, disrupting communication between the brain and the rest of the body.

notes.title: The Human Brain
points: Forebrain: Cerebrum (Intelligence, memory, voluntary actions), Thalamus, Hypothalamus (Homeostasis, body temp, hunger).
Midbrain: Relay centre for visual and auditory impulses.
Hindbrain: Cerebellum (Balance, coordination), Pons, Medulla Oblongata (Involuntary actions like heart rate, breathing).

notes.title: Spinal Cord
points: Conducts impulses to and from the brain.
Centre for reflex actions.

realworld.title: Stroke
realworld.description: Damage to specific brain areas due to interrupted blood supply can lead to loss of specific functions (e.g., speech or movement) controlled by that area.

notes.title: Divisions
points: Somatic Neural System (SNS): Relays impulses from CNS to skeletal muscles (Voluntary).
Autonomic Neural System (ANS): Relays impulses from CNS to involuntary organs/smooth muscles.
ANS subdivisions: Sympathetic (Fight or Flight) and Parasympathetic (Rest and Digest).

realworld.title: Adrenaline Rush
realworld.description: In dangerous situations, the sympathetic system increases heart rate and alertness to prepare the body for 'fight or flight'.

notes.title: Mechanism
points: Sudden, involuntary response to a stimulus.
Reflex Arc: Stimulus -> Receptor -> Sensory Neuron -> Spinal Cord (Interneuron) -> Motor Neuron -> Effector (Muscle/Gland) -> Response.

realworld.title: Knee-Jerk Reflex
realworld.description: Doctors tap the tendon below the kneecap to test reflex action; the leg kicks out involuntarily.

realworld.title: Touching Hot Object
realworld.description: Pulling your hand away instantly upon touching a hot stove protects tissues from burn damage before the brain even processes the pain.

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Ductless glands: Secrete hormones directly into the blood.
Hormones: Non-nutrient chemicals acting as intercellular messengers, produced in trace amounts.
Major Glands: Pituitary, Thyroid, Adrenal, Pancreas (Islets of Langerhans), Parathyroid, Pineal, Gonads.

notes.title: Pituitary Hormones
points: Growth Hormone (GH): Regulates growth. Hypersecretion -> Gigantism; Hyposecretion -> Dwarfism.
TSH: Stimulates thyroid.
ADH (Vasopressin): Water reabsorption in kidneys.

notes.title: Thyroid Hormones
points: Thyroxine (T4) & Triiodothyronine (T3): Regulate Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR).
Iodine is essential for synthesis. Deficiency Causes Goitre.

notes.title: Pancreatic Hormones
points: Insulin (Beta cells): Lowers blood glucose (Glycogenesis).
Glucagon (Alpha cells): Increases blood glucose (Glycogenolysis).

notes.title: Adrenal Hormones
points: Adrenaline/Noradrenaline: Emergency hormones (increase heart rate, alertness).

realworld.title: Diabetes Mellitus
realworld.description: Lack of insulin leads to high blood sugar levels, requiring patients to carefully manage diet or take insulin injections.

realworld.title: Salt Iodization
realworld.description: Common salt is fortified with iodine to prevent thyroid disorders (Goitre) in the population.

notes.title: Types of Receptors
points: Membrane-bound Receptors: For protein hormones (e.g., Insulin). Generate second messengers (like cAMP) to regulate cellular metabolism.
Intracellular Receptors: For steroid hormones (e.g., Estrogen) and iodothyronines. Hormone-receptor complex interacts with genome to regulate gene expression.

notes.title: Regulation
points: Hormone secretion is regulated by feedback loops to maintain homeostasis.
Negative Feedback: Rising hormone levels inhibit further secretion (Most common). e.g., High TSH stimulates T4, high T4 inhibits TSH.
Positive Feedback: Hormone release stimulates further release (Rare). e.g., Oxytocin during childbirth.

realworld.title: Thermostat Analogy
realworld.description: Just as a thermostat turns off the heater when the room gets hot, the body reduces hormone secretion when levels are sufficient.
